image:image.image:title: seriola-zonata588.
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Basal to the four-eyed fish, sea robin and gurnard in the LRT is this taxon, Seriola sonata, the banded rudder fish. Note the lack of cheek bones and the tentative appearance of the palatine outside of the palate.

image:image.image:title: optimum_pterosaur_wing_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. When Zanzaria et al. 2016 used math to model the optimum pterosaur wing, they found a narrow chord (red), as in figure 7, worked better than the Elgin, Hone and Frey 2011 wing (black).

image:image.image:title: macready_q_pterosaur_inflight588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Paul MacCready's flying pterosaur model had longer wings than Q. sp., with its vestigial distal wing phalanges. Here the model and its inspiration are shown to the same length.

image:image.image:title: pterodactylus_vienna2020-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. This is Figure 1B of Martin-Silverstone et al. 2020 where they mislabel the left and right wings. Colors added to show the extent of the wing membrane. See figure 4 for an animation of this fossil.

image:image.image:title: pterosaur_wing_2020-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Above: freehand image from Martin-Silverstone 2020 of Quetzalcoatlus northropi wing. Pink arrows call out errors. Below: Traced image of Q. sp. wing.

image:image.image:title: Robert L. Carroll

image:image.image:title: Austriadraco-mandible-bsp1994-1000
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Austriadraco, BSp 1994 I51, a Triassic pterosaur mandible. Is it exposed in medial view or lateral view? Below the line is Eudimorphodon, which preserves mandibles in lateral and medial view. Which one is more similar to Austriadraco? You decide. Click to enlarge. Also note the tiny mandibular fenestra in the lateral view of Eudimorphodon not replicated on the medial view and apparently caused by a shift in the covering bone. Arrow points to apparent broken strip of bone that would otherwise have made the long light blue bone continuous.

image:image.image:title: onychodus_naris
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Onychodus is typical of most fish having dual external nares strictly for olfactory sensing. Gill covers are part of the respiratory apparatus.

image:image.image:title: Trypanognathus-breathing588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Animation of air-breathing in basal tetrapods with weak lungs inflated by contraction and expansion of the throat sac, rather than gill irrigation powered by the reduced here buccal bones.

image:image.image:title: Trypanognathus-skull3views588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Phylogenetic genesis of a dorsal naris better suited to dry air respiration.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The skull of Yonghesuchus now compares well with that of Litargosuchus (figure 2).

image:image.image:title: erpetosuchids588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Erpetosuchus and kin illustrated to scale. Parringtonia + Tarjadia + Erpetosuchus now nest with Decuriasuchus basal to Poposaurs + Archosauria.

image:image.image:title: dsungaripterus-palate-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Dsungaripterus palate from Chen et al. 2020 with colors and diagrams (above) from Peters 2000 added. Note only a vestige remains of the lateral process of the palatine. The extent of the jugal is a guess here. Pink = pterygoid. Blue = palatine. Gold = ectopterygoid. Â In Chen et al. the line leading toward the abbreviation pl points to the maxilla.

image:image.image:title: dsungaripterus_tooth_tips588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Dsungaripterus single teeth at the tips of the jaws. Phylogenetically these began with Germanodactylus (Fig. 4).

image:image.image:title: lagosuchus-2019pelvis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Lagosuchus in situ preserves impressions of two additional sacrals. Phylogenetic bracketing between taxa with four sacrals suggesting looking for these impressions.

image:image.image:title: china.tapejarid.complete.insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Complete basal tapejarid without identification. Please provide a museum number or citation if possible.

image:image.image:title: A New Crocodylomorph Archosaur from the Upper Triassic of North
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Dromicosuchus makes a first appearance here at PH.WP.com. Note the similarities to the YPM specimen. Phylogenetic analysis nests the YPM specimen apart from Dromicosuchus by 20 steps.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Vjushkovia, Decuriasuchus and Pagosvenator to scale. The basalmost Vjushkovia is the outgroup for the other two taxa in the LRT.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Pagosvenator skull in lateral view and reconstructed. The unknown bone in the mandible is a fragment of the jugal.

image:image.image:title: tarjadia588

image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Dibothrosuchus nests basal to all later quadrupedal crocs, including marine crocs, in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: sciurumimus_overall588

image:image.image:title: greererpeton_tarsals588

image:image.image:title: nyctiphuretus_huehuecuetzpalli_tarsus588

image:image.image:title: protorosaurus_pes588

image:image.image:title: tritosaur_tarsals588

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Ectosteorhachis skull from Thomson 1966 with layers to show the brain case and 'palatoquadrate'. Some bones are relabeled.

image:image.image:title: hyomandibular_evolution588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Hyomandibular evolution from the first dichotomy of bony fish to Gephyrostegus. The hyomandibular evolves to become the stapes. Note the hyomandibula contact with the intertemporal, quadrate and pterygoid, sometimes fused to these bones.

image:image.image:title: Oculudentavis-khaungraae-aof1-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. CT scan of Oculudentavis from Xing et al. 2020, colors added. Antorbital fenestra here is mailer than in Cosesaurus, but still visible.

image:image.image:title: Oculudentavis-khaungraae-aof2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. CT scan from Xing et al. 2020, colors added to show antorbital fenestra. Note the wrinkling of the maxilla reacting to the twisting of the tiny, fragile skull during taphonomy.

image:image.image:title: rise_of_fishes_long_1995
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Rise of Fishes 1995 book by fish expert John Long.

image:image.image:title: Gregorius_rexi_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Tiny Gregorius rexi nests basal to moray and gulper eels and also basal to all bony fish in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Amia_Anableps_Anguilla588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Amia, Anableps and Anguilla are related to one another in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: anableps_skull-2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Anableps skull CT scan images from Michel et al. 2015.

image:image.image:title: anableps_tetrophthalmus
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The four-eyed fish. Drawing from Gregory 1938. Tetrapod homolog colors applied here.

image:image.image:title: basal_vertebrates_fish_cladogram2020
image:image.image:caption: Figure x. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal vertebrates. This represents the latest hypothesis of interrelationships and includes several changes from prior versions of this section.

image:image.image:title: gasterosteus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Skull of the stickleback, Gasterosteus, with bones colored here. Compared to figure 1.

image:image.image:title: seriola-zonata588.
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Gregory 1933 did not illustrate a jugal and lacrimal for Seriola zonata, but the cladogram indicates they should be there. We find them in the photo.

image:image.image:title: Flagellipinna-rhomboides-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Flagellipinna is a sister to the bone fish, Alubula, in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: basal_vertebrates_fish_cladogram2020
image:image.image:caption: Figure x. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal vertebrates. This represents the latest hypothesis of interrelationships and includes several changes from prior versions of this section.

image:image.image:title: albula.vulpes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Albula vulpes skull with highly derived facial bones reidentified here. Note the lateral premaxillary processes and 'floating' cheek bones. Green vertebrae are caudals.

image:image.image:title: albula.vulpes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Albula vulpes skull with bones reidentified here. Note the lateral premaxillary processes and 'floating' cheek bones.

image:image.image:title: ezcurra_cladogram5887
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. From Ezcurra et al. 2020 with an overlay based on LRT results.

image:image.image:title: Luchibang-xingzhe-pelvis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. Pelvic area of Luchibang from Hone et al. 2020 with elements, including the overlooked tiny tail (green in ghosted oval) colorized.

image:image.image:title: Luchibang_skull_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Luchibang skull in situ and reconstructed. Contra Hone et al. 2020, the cranial portion of the skull is visible and can be reconstructed.

image:image.image:title: Luchibang_recon2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. New tracings from Hone et al. 2020 of Luchibang (spelled Luichibang in the caption). Valid istiodactylids (see below) have much larger wings, much shorter metacarpals, much shorter necks and much smaller feet.Â

image:image.image:title: albula.vulpes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Albula vulpes, a bonefish, has a odd sort of skull most closely related to the stickleback, Gasterosteus.

image:image.image:title: tarpon_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Tarpon (Megalops) skull with tetrapod skull colors added.

image:image.image:title: rhombichthys-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Rhombichthys skull in situ, as originally traced, as originally reconstructed and as traced here using DGS methods. See figure 1 for a reconstruction with bones replace to their in vivo positions.

image:image.image:title: rhombichthys_overall588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Rhombichthys, a tiny Late Cretaceous tarpon with deep scutes creating a sternum.

image:image.image:title: Tristychius-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. CT scans of Tristychius skull from Coates et al. 2019.

image:image.image:title: tristychius2angelshark588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Tristychius, a basal shark from the Early Carboniferous, compared to descendant taxa, two angel sharks.

image:image.image:title: mesacanthus_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Early Devoniann Mesacanthus in situ. This 3 cm fish is a typical acanthodian here traced using DGS methods and reconstructed. Distinct from other spiny sharks, this one lacks large cheek plates, as in the extant Notopterus (Fig. 3).

image:image.image:title: notopterus.588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The extant knife fish or featherback, Notopterus, is an extant descendant of spiny sharks in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: mesacanthus_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Early Devoniann Mesacanthus in situ. This 3 cm fish is a typical acanthodian here traced using DGS methods and reconstructed.

image:image.image:title: amia_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Skull of the extant bowfin (Amia). Compare to figure 3.

image:image.image:title: protoamia_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Protoamia skull.

image:image.image:title: amia_skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Skeleton of the extant bowfin (Amia).

image:image.image:title: protoamia_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Protoamia in situ and reconstructed using DGS methods.

image:image.image:title: Tarrasius-problematicus_diagrams588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Diagram of Tarrasius reconstructions from Sallan 2012, colorized here with the addition of the DGS tracing at lower right.

image:image.image:title: tarrasius.skull.insituNHM-P18062
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Sallan 2012 the NHM-P18062 skull of Tarrasius, the tadpole mimic. DGS colors added and used to create the reconstruction shown here. Note the complete lack of utility offered by the Sallan 2012 tracing.

image:image.image:title: xenacanthus_skull_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Xenacanthus skull with DGS colors added to show the unfused mandible bones.

image:image.image:title: xenacanthus_overall_diagram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Xenacanthus diagram with dorsal vertebrae colorized. Note the difference between the skull of this species and the one in figure 2.

image:image.image:title: polyodon-stained-skeleton-baby588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. A shark-like juvenile paddlefish (Polyodon) has teeth and lacks a paddle-snout. Compare to the adult in figure 1.

image:image.image:title: Tarrasius_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Tarrasius skull from Sallan 2012, colors added.

image:image.image:title: Tarrasius.overall588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Sallan 2012, reconstruction of Tarrasius with colors added. Note the five vertebral regions.

image:image.image:title: bonnerichthys_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Reconstructed Bonnerichthys plus, at bottom and ghosted, Osteoglossum to scale.

image:image.image:title: Bonnerichthys-gladius-parts588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Bonnerichthys parts from Friedman et al. 2010 and colorized here.

image:image.image:title: pachycormus-3D_BRLSI-M1332
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. The BRLS specimen attributed to Pachycormus by Cawley et al. now nesting with Hydrolycus, sans the large fangs.

image:image.image:title: trachinocephalus_hybodus_amia588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. A sister to Hybodus gave rise to a basal dichotomy in bony fish. Basal taxa immediately following this split include Trachinocephalus on the clade leading to tetrapods and Amia on the clade leading to most other traditional teleosts.

image:image.image:title: protosphyraena2xskulls588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Late Cretaceous, Protosphyraena, may have a sharp nose, but look at the pattern of those fangs... identical to those of Hydrolycus (Fig. 1).

image:image.image:title: hydrolycus.skull.complete588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Hydrolycus, the extant dogtooth characin seems to have unique fangs. But a closely related extinct taxon, Protosphyraena, also has fangs.

image:image.image:title: tuna_thunnus_skull2
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Revised colors applied to this skull of Thunnus, the tuna.

image:image.image:title: hippoglossus-flounder.skull_top_bot588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Revised skull colors for Hippoglossus the flounder now nests it with Thunnus the tuna.

image:image.image:title: Cynoglossus-puncticeps-588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 6. Cynoglosses is the extant tongue sole, a flatfish so derived that the pectorals are absent, the tail is continuous with the dorsal and anal fins, the mouth is no longer terminal and both eyes are in the ventral half of the left side of whatever remains of the skull.

image:image.image:title: Psettodes-erumei_invivo
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Psettodes is the most primitive living flatfish. Note the dorsal position of the right eye.

image:image.image:title: Amphistium588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Amphistium is transitional between Heteronectes and flatfish.

image:image.image:title: Heteronectes-chaneti588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Heteronectes is transitional between Polydactylus and flatfish.

image:image.image:title: flounder-DNA-evo588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Friedman et al. genomic study puts flatfish together (orange and yellow added).

image:image.image:title: 8-flatfish-cladograms
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Eight cladograms printed by Harrington et al. 2016, four of which recover a monophyletic clade of flatfish. Four others recover a diphyletic split. None of these duplicate the diphyletic results recovered in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: polydactylus_onwhite
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The threadfin, Polydactylus, also splits the pectoral fin to form threadlike feelers.

image:image.image:title: Dapedium_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The skull of Dapedium (Early Jurassic) from Smithwick 2015, plus original tracing plus DGS colors and colors restored to in vivo positions.

image:image.image:title: Stensioella_AMNH588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The bottom dweller, Stensioella, is derived from placoderms and angel sharks and nests at the base of lobefin fish, some of which give rise to most ray fin fish, while others give rise to stem tetrapods.

image:image.image:title: stensioella_cu_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure x. Stensioella skull in higher resolution. The left side is missing the skull roofing bones, so we're looking inside the skull.

image:image.image:title: basal-vertebratra-cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal vertebrates, chiefly fish.

image:image.image:title: A new specimen of Prolacerta broomi from the lower Fremouw Forma
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Small Prolacerta specimen AMNH 9520 from Spiekman 2018 compared to scale with Vellbergia.

image:image.image:title: Vellbergia-comparison-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Vellbegia compared to the lepidosaurs it would nest with if Prolacerta and all Archosauromorpha were deleted.

image:image.image:title: basal_vertebrates_preoperculum
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal vertebrates and highlighting the appearance of the preoperculum in various ways. Note the reappearance of the preoperculum in the tetrapods within the Â Ossinodus clade.

image:image.image:title: Flagellipinna-rhomboides-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Flagellipinna skull in situ, original tracing, DGS colors applied and reconstruction. Small skull is Salmo the salmon, not to scale.

image:image.image:title: Flagellipinna-rhomboides-overall588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. One of four specimens of Flagellipinna from Cawley and xx, 2019.

image:image.image:title: prolacerta-bpI-1-47-vellbergia588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Prolacerta and 'Vellbergia' to scale.

image:image.image:title: Vellbergia-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Vellbergia in situ, original line drawing, DGS colors apple and reconstruction. Note the quadrate break occurs during taphonomic crushing of the curved bone. Scale bar = 5mm. So the skull is about 1.5cm in length, quite tiny.

image:image.image:title: barameda-insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Barameda skull in situ, traced using DGS methods and reconstructed in lateral view. Compare to the moray eel (Gymnothorax) in figure 3.)

image:image.image:title: Moray_Eel_Skull_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The skull of the moray eel, Gymnothorax, in 3 views. Colors added as homologs to tetrapod skull bones. The nares exit is above the eyes.

image:image.image:title: gooloogongia-and-barameda588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Gooloogongia and Barameda from Jeffery 2012. Compare Barameda here to figure 2.

image:image.image:title: Chondrichthyes_cladogram2020_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The addition of Megachasma to the LRT provides a transitional taxon between primitive sharks and derived sharks + rays.

image:image.image:title: Megachasma_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Megachasma skull is made of cartilage and several jaw elements are fused together, as in other higher sharks.

image:image.image:title: Megachasma_invivio588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Megachasma in vivo. Note the single cusp teeth.

image:image.image:title: anarhichas.skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull of the wolffish, Anarhichas. Compare to the pupfish in figure 3.

image:image.image:title: Pseudorestias-lirimensis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Tiny Pseudorestias, the pupfish, nests with the large wolffish (Figs. 1, 2) in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Esox_masquinongy_muskie_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The muskelunge, Esox masquinongy, now nests in the LRT alongside the channel catfish (Ictalurus punctatus), Fig. 3).

image:image.image:title: ictalurus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The channel catfish, Ictalurus, skull and lateral view in vivo.

image:image.image:title: Esox_masquinongy_invivo588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The muskie (Esox masquinongy) in vivo.

image:image.image:title: mola_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The ocean sunfish (Mola) seems to be the opposite of the flying fish (Exocoetus), but these two nest with each other in the LRT based on skeletal traits.

image:image.image:title: lampris-skull2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. More traits unite the opah with the flying fish than separate these two, given the present taxon list. Note the deep coracoids, as in birds and pterosaurs, here again used to flap the pectoral fins.

image:image.image:title: Origin_of-Placoderms_Materpiscis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Origin of placoderms featuring Chirodus, Austroptyctodus, Coccosteus and other pertinent taxa.

image:image.image:title: austroptyctodus.Chirodus.skulls588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Cheirodus skull compared to Austroptyctodus skull, which was reassembled by Miles and Young 1977 from disassembled bones.

image:image.image:title: balistes-capriscus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The queen triggerfish, Balistes, is related to Mola in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Rranzania588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ranzania from Johnson and Britz 2004 in various degrees of dissection.

image:image.image:title: wolf-herring-chirocentrus.skull588

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Chauliodus, the viperfish, skull. Compared to the wolf herring in figure 1.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull of the salmon, Salmo. Compare to Amia, the bowfin (Fig. 2).

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Scomberomorus again, this time with the jugal highlighted in cyan.

image:image.image:title: fish_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Updated subset of the LRT focusing on basal vertebrates (fish). Arrow points to Hybodus. This tree does not agree with previous fish tree topologies.

image:image.image:title: origin_of_catfish_placoderms588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. Taxa descending from Hybodus the Mesozoic 'shark' with a likely genesis in the Silurian.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Diplacanthus, a Mid-Devonian acanthodian with proportions similar to those of a young Hybodus, shorter with longer spines.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Diagram of Hybodus in vivo and skeleton plus teeth.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1 (added 01/27/2020 with a current interpretation of skull bones on Hybodus, plus a reconstruction. Note the retention of external gill bars.

image:image.image:title: Pachycormus-overall588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Pachycormus fossil. Pelvic fins vestigial near vestigial anal fin. See figure 2 for closeup of the skull.

image:image.image:caption: Figure A. Classic diagram of Cladoselache skull, colors added.

image:image.image:title: cladoselache-cmnh_ventral588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Cladoselache specimen in ventral view. Note the rostrum and mandible tip have been restored as a gray tone here. Prior workers imagined a bullet-shaped skull, but see figure 2.

image:image.image:title: Doliodus2020-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Doliodus skull and pectoral region with lateral reconstruction at right. Note the narrow pectoral region relative to the wide spread occiput. Apparently this fish had a narrower body than head.

image:image.image:title: bonyfish_cladogram2020
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal chordates, vertebrates and bony fish not related to tetrapods. Scomber and Istiophorus are new additions to the gold clade.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull of Iniopteryx in situ and reconstructed.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. This is where the high forehead of the male mahi-mahi (Corphaena) comes from, one of the very few fish with a frontal crest.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Yutyrannus compared to Tyrannosaurus and Allosaurus.

image:image.image:title: Zhenyuanlong_vs_velociraptor
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Tianyuraptor and Zhenyuanlong compared to Tyrannosaurus and to Velociraptor. The two taxa in question traditionally nest with the latter.

image:image.image:title: Deinocheirus-reconstructions588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Deinocheirus specimens and a composite illustration.

image:image.image:title: deinocheirus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The skull of Deinocheirus. Note how the mandible does not completely close cranially when the anterior tips touch. I wonder if this was a sieving organ lined with baleen-like structures? That hypothesis goes with the very deep mandible and the equal lengths of both upper and lower jaws.

image:image.image:title: sinocalliopteryx-feathers588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Sinocalliopteryx currently nests as a provisional sister to Deinocheirus, awaiting the discovery of transitional sister taxa.

image:image.image:title: squid-pterosaur-tooth-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Plesioteuthis squid in situ with tooth. Reconstructions of Plesioteuthis (above) and the n81 specimen attributed to the largest known Rhamphorhynhcus, which has a matching tooth. The question is: could that pterosaur eat that squid? Or did it change its mind after biting the squid?

image:image.image:title: tripod_fish_bones588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Bathypterois, the deep sea tripod fish, shown with diagram of jaws and palate from Sulak 2006, then colored and matched to the in vivo specimen.

image:image.image:title: helodus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Helodus skull drawings from xxx 1938 show no skull sutures. Colors are applied with blending edges to show were bones are based on tetrapod homologs.

image:image.image:title: rachycentron-skull588

Yellow boxes indicate facultatively bipedal extant lepidosaurs.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Champsosaurus from Dugeon et al. Here the nasal is the ascending process of the premaxilla. The prefrontal is the nasal fused to the prefrontal. The postorbital is the postfrontal and vice versa.

image:image.image:title: novi_04377.1_24.tp
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Tchoria and phylogenetic bracketing help identify bones in the skull of Champsosaurus (Fig. 2).

image:image.image:title: Asfaltomylos_patagonicus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Asfaltomylos (MPEF-PV 1671) is a tiny mandible with teeth from in Jurassic strata in South America. Note the shape of the posterior premolar and how it relates to the giant posterior premolar in Carpolestes. The canine is tall. Not sure if Asfaltomylos had large incisors. Either way it does not matter, based on comparisons to Echinosorex and Erinaceus, the living moonrat and hedgehog.

image:image.image:title: shuotherium_medial588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Medial view of Shuotherium. The last premolar is similar to the first molar, the coronoid process is tiny and the retroarticular process is absent, all distinct from Asfaltomylos (Fig. 1).

image:image.image:title: ostrom_before_after588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. John Ostrom, from young paleo stud to elderly professorial type.

image:image.image:title: pvl-4597w_Cyanocritta

image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on the Crocodylomorpha, dorsal scutes, elongate proximal carpals, bipedality and clades.

image:image.image:title: prorotodactylus_manus_pes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Brusatte 2018, colored here. The caption reports, "a handprint overlapping a footprint.' In reality the handprint was put down first, followed by the footprint. Given the presented lighting with shadows below, this is a natural cast of the original impression.

image:image.image:title: gatorwalk_2013_06_02
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. GIF animation of a very short-legged extant crocodilian demonstrating how the toes nearly touch the wrist during the step cycle. No legs more elongate than Diandongosuchus need to be imagined.

image:image.image:title: prorotodactylus_niedzwiedzki588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Model of hypothetical trackmaker of Prorotodactylus alongside its creator, paleontologist, Grzegorz Niedzwiedzki (ghosted to bring out the model) from Brusatte 2018.

image:image.image:title: prorotodactylus_Diandongosuchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Manus and pes casts of Prorotodactylus compared to manus and pes of Diandongosuchus (Fig. 4).

image:image.image:title: diandongosuchus-recon588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 2. Diandongosuchus (2012) compares well with Prorotodactylus tracks. These legs are long enough to make overlapping tracks. Diandongosuchus is closer to the genesis of phytosaurs and their sisters, the chaÃ±aresuchids than to dinosaurs.

image:image.image:title: pvl-4597w_Cyanocitta
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. The genesis of the Archosauria embodied in PVL 4597 to scale with a modern archosaur, Cyanocitta, the blue jay.

image:image.image:title: origin_of-dinosaurs-to-scale
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The origin of dinosaurs in the LRT to scale. Gray arrows show the direction of evolution. This image includes Decuriasuchus, Turfanosuchus, Gracilisuchus, Lewisuchus, Pseudhesperosuchus, Trialestes, Herrerasaurus, Tawa and Eoraptor. Â Note the phylogenetic miniaturization at the origin of Archosauria (Crocs + Dinos).

image:image.image:title: theropodsLRTsize
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on theropods and basal birds. Colors added for large (greater than a meter), medium (about a meter), and small (less than a meter) in length. Compare to figure 2 from Rezende et al. Note the depth of small taxa, some of which give rise to large taxa.

image:image.image:title: theropods_rezendeetal2020-588

image:image.image:title: sturgeonskul_lacrimal588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Old woodcut illustration labeling the upper mouth tube bone the lacrimal. Mn = mandible. h = quadrate. g = hyobranchial. Weave of bones above the lacrimal are palatal bones (pterygoid, ectopterygoid, palatine and vomer, plus a remnant gill bar. This taxon really exaggerates the rostrum, similar to the related spoonbill.

image:image.image:title: origin_of_jaws-2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure x. Chondrosteus was revised and no longer fits here. Pachycormus is inserted in its place.

image:image.image:title: origin_of_jaws588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Top to bottom: Thelodus a soft jawless fish with a ventral oral opening and gill slits, perhaps a hint of diamond-shaped armor laterally. Hemicyclaspis, adds extensive armor. Acipenser, a sturgeon with a protrusible tube for a mouth and reduced armor. Chondrosteus, a toothless shark-like fish with no armor.

image:image.image:title: Gnathostomata_LRT588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT with the addition of several jawless taxa.

image:image.image:title: sturgeonskul_lacrimal588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Old woodcut illustration labeling the upper mouth tube bone the lacrimal.

image:image.image:title: sturgeon.pseudoscaphirhynchus588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 2. The small sturgeon Pseudoscahirhynchus skull in several views. Note the perforated rostrum (nasal) sensitive to prey hiding in mud. The mouth is reduced to a tiny sucking tube disconnected from the quadrate. Even so, this sturgeon nests with sharks in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Mako-shark-Isurus-oxyrinchus588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. The mako shark (Isurus oxyrinchus) skull and skeleton. Note the confluent lateral temporal fenestra separated from the orbit by a tiny postorbital.

image:image.image:title: sturgeon.pseudoscaphirhynchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull of Pseudoscaphorhynchus. Note the mouth is created by the lacrimal and surangular, not the maxilla and dentary, which are tooth-bearing bones in more derived fish.

image:image.image:title: sturgeon.pseudoscaphirhynchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull of Pseudoscaphorhynchus. Note the mouth is created by the lacrimal and angular, not the maxilla and dentary, which are tooth-bearing bones in more derived fish.

image:image.image:title: cephalaspis_pseudoscaphorhynchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The osteostracan Cephalaspis (above) compared to the sturgeon Pseudoscaphorhynchus (below). The similarities of these armored morphologies have been overlooked previously. In both cases the jawless or tubular mouth is below the skull, the former towards the front, the latter below the eyes.

image:image.image:title: Desmatochelys padillai800
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Desmatochelys padillai at 120 mya, the oldest known sea turtle.

image:image.image:title: santanachelys-shell

image:image.image:title: Serrasalmus-rhombeus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skeleton of the red eye piranha, Serrasalmus rhombeus, in lateral view. Distinct from its bottom foraging predecessor, Alma, the skull and torso of this more agile swimmer are deeper and narrower.

image:image.image:title: Kudnu-mackinlayi588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Kudnu colorized using DGS and slight restored postcranially, shown 10x natural size at a 72 dpi standard screen resolution. Here's a taxon basal to Stephanospondylus, pareiasaurs and turtles. Prior workers excluded Stephanospondylus from their studies.

image:image.image:title: turtle_origins_schoch_sues-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Competing turtle origin hypotheses. Bottom: from Schoch and Sues 2019. Top: From the LRT, which tests all taxa from Schoch and Sues, then adds over 1000 more.

image:image.image:title: jeholbaatar-mandible-ear588

image:image.image:title: jeholbaatar-ear-diagram2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Jeholobaatar images from Wang, Meng and Weng 2019. Rat ear bones photo from Li, Gao, Ding and Salvi 2015. Correction label added here.

image:image.image:title: csotonyi-mimodactylus-repaired
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. Artwork in Kellner et al. of Mimodactylus by Julius Csotonyi. Second frame shows repairs to morphology needed to bring this illustration up to date.

image:image.image:title: turinia-holotype588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Turinia holotype from Donoghue and Smith 2001, plus their diagram, plus DGS tracings. Note the anterior extension of the pectoral fin, as in manta rays.

image:image.image:title: rhincodon_gills_head588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The whale shark, Rhincodon, has an enormous gill chamber for capturing planktonic prey.

image:image.image:title: y-Thelodont_gills588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Loganellia, from the Silurian, had a large, wide gill chamber inside a low skull.

image:image.image:title: manta_ray-gills588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The gill chamber and digestive track of Manta shown in ventral view.

image:image.image:title: turinia_gills588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Turinia is a basal ray, possibly ancestral to mantas or cow nose rays.

image:image.image:title: permian_sponges_at_night588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Permian sea floor at night. The largest prey items here are also the softest and most plentiful and easiest to graze on at night for a growing Helicoprion: the tall sponges. Just guessing giving the present data.

image:image.image:title: helicoprion_hydrolagus_cu588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 3. Closeup of figure 2.

image:image.image:title: helicoprion_hydrolagus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Helicoprion ÂµCT scans, model made from scans, in vivo image with shark-like proportions, and matched against chimaera (Hydrolagus) jaws.

image:image.image:title: helicoprion_whorl_alone588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. Helicoprion fossil. Evidently this was an adult based on the number of smaller teeth present here.

image:image.image:title: Birkenia-gills300
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Birkenia is basically an armored Metaspriggina with a tail fin.

image:image.image:title: Drepanaspis-gemuendenensis-gills588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. The large gill chamber (cyan) of Early Devonian Drepanaspis.

image:image.image:title: arandaspis588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 3. Arandaspis lived inside its gill chamber shell and armored tail.

image:image.image:title: poraspis-gills588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Poraspis fuses the lateral gill plates together for greater armor, leaving only a slender single common opening for the exiting water. This was probably a sedentary taxon due to its inability to respire at a great rate.

image:image.image:title: salp_gills588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 5. Salp variety. Here the atrium is the animal with other organs inside the atrium.

image:image.image:title: tunicate_recon588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 4. A tunicate diagram turned on its side to replicate the morphology of the lancelet (Fig. 2). Here the atriopore enlarges to become a exit siphon. The cilia are reduced. The gill chamber is greatly enlarged.

image:image.image:title: lancelet588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Extant lancelet (genus: Amphioxus) in cross section and lateral view. The gill basket nearly fills an atrium, which intakes water + food, sends the food into the intestine and expels the rest of the water.

image:image.image:title: coelomate588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Hypothetical chordate ancestor to known chordates. This is the starting point for looking at gills and throats in basal chordates and vertebrates.

image:image.image:title: dintwQ
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. When they had to animate Quetzalcoatlus, they got rid of that membrane down to the ankles.

image:image.image:title: silurian_catfish_face588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Silurian catfish face

image:image.image:title: thelod-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Originally considered another Silurian Thelodus, this specimen nests with catfish in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: najash_snake_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on geckos and their sister snake ancestors.

image:image.image:title: najash_hips588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Najash hips from earlier finds.

image:image.image:title: najash2019-skullCT588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Najash compared to Tetrapodophis (the last snake with legs) and Loxocemus, an extant burrowing snake without legs.

image:image.image:title: Vjushkovia_Garjainia588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Vjushkova holotype compared to Gargainia. These two nest together in the LRT, but not by much. Both the antorbital and lateral temporal regions differ greatly.

image:image.image:title: clarias-skull588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. Clarias, the walking catfish is a living placoderm with skull bones colorized as homologs of those in Entelognathus (Fig. 2). Here the mandible shifts forward and the opercular shifts backwards relative to Entelongnathus in the Silurian.

image:image.image:title: clarias_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT focusing on Claria and other basal vertebrates.

image:image.image:title: clarias_walking_catfish_588invivo
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Clarias batrachus, the walking catfish, in vivo. The pelvic fin is tiny. The single dorsal fin is elongate. The anal fin is also elongate. The skull is flat and provided with sensory barbels.

image:image.image:title: cheirolepis_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cheirolepis skull (left) with skull bones colorized as in Osteolepis (right) and Enteognathus, figure 1. Colors make bone identification much easier. Note the post opercular bone differences between Osteolepis and Cheirolepis indicating separate and convergent derivation, based on present data.

image:image.image:title: cheirolepis_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cheirolepis skull (left) with skull bones colorized as in Osteolepis (right) and Enteognathus, figure 1. Colors make bone identification much easier.

image:image.image:title: placoderm-sarcopterygian-skull-roof588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Zhu et al. 2013 SuppData showing placoderm and other basal vertebrate skull roofs. Note: Entelognathus is the only taxon without frontals, which I found in the photos of the fossil, figure 2.

image:image.image:title: entelognathus_lat_dorsal588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The placoderm, Entelognathus, is widely considered the outgroup to the crossopterygians, the stem tetrapods. Compare the skull bones to those of Polypterus (Fig. 1) and Tinirau (Fig. 3). The posterior is unknown.

image:image.image:title: howidipterus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Middle Devonian lungfish, Howidipterus, with subdivided skull bones colorized here to match those in the placoderm Entelognathus (Fig. 2).

image:image.image:title: BasalVertebratesLRT588
image:image.image:caption: Figure A. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal vertebrates (fish).

image:image.image:title: Metaspriggina588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. An early jawless, finless, lancelet-like fish from the Cambrian, Metaspriggina. Compare the placement of the eyes here with Birkenia in figures 2 and 3.

image:image.image:title: thelodus_GLAHM-V8304face
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Ventral view of the GLAHM V830 specimen of Thelodus. This appears to have fang-like teeth, but these may be sharp cilia. The mandible appears to be a dead end experiment convergent with the mandible of all other vertebrates.

image:image.image:title: birkenia-elegans-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Birkenia in situ with facial bones labeled. Frontals and quadratojugals evolve later.

image:image.image:title: Birkenia-elegans588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. Birkenia in situ and diagrams.

image:image.image:title: thelodus_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Specimen identified as Thelodus by Long 1995. It has an underslung mandible and long rostral teeth along with long pectoral fins, distinct from Loganellia.

image:image.image:title: y-Thelodont588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Loganellia, a thelodont with whale shark shape including dorsal fin. Image from OldRedSandstone.com. This appears to be Loganellia, not Thelodus (Fig. 7).

image:image.image:title: rhincodon_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Â Manta compared to Thelodus (Loganellia) and Rhincodon. All three have a terminal mouth essentially straight across, between the lateral eyes, distinct from most fish.

image:image.image:title: loganellia-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Loganellia scotica in situ and after DGS coloring. Several details are recovered here that identify this as a little sister to Rhincodon, the whale shark. Photo from Birkknowesaffairs.com. Specimen from museum?

image:image.image:title: thelodus-face588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Closeup of Thelodus' face labeled.

image:image.image:title: squatina_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on basalmost taxa. Here jawless Thelodus is the new outgroup taxon, bringing with it the sharks, ratfish and sturgeons.

image:image.image:title: hoplosternum-dorsal588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Hoplosternum skull in dorsal view. Now this really looks like a placoderm, but the details nest it closer to the channel catfish.

image:image.image:title: hoplosternum-dorsal588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Hoplosternum skull in dorsal view. Now this really looks like a placoderm, but the details nest it closer to the channel catfish.

image:image.image:title: kwi-kwi-amored-catfish-Hoplosternum-littorale

image:image.image:caption: Figure A. The skull of Hoplosternum in lateral view with bones identified by their tetrapod colors.

image:image.image:title: gemuenida_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 9. Subset of the LRT focusing on fish. The two nominal Gemuendia specimens are highlighted.

image:image.image:title: ictalurus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. The extant channel catfish, Ictalurus. Note the lack of cheekbones, maxilla and lacrimal.

image:image.image:title: Gemuendina-stuertzi_KGM-1983_306
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. the KGM 1983 306 specimen referred to Gemuendina. This one is closer to the extant channel catfish, Ictalurus.

image:image.image:title: KGM-1983_308
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Specimen KGM-1983_308 has a dorsal naris with closely appressed openings.

image:image.image:title: gemuendina_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Gemuendian reconstructed. The gray shapes are gill cover plates. The rest of the bones nest Gemuendina closer to the living bichir, Polypterus. This may not be the holotype specimen, but an improperly referred specimen. Not sure yet.

image:image.image:title: gemuendina_hirez588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Gemuendina in situ with DGS colors applied to scattered skull bones and gill covers. Light red curved bones represent the pectoral girdle, not ray-like pectoral fins. This may have been less ray-like than traditionally portrayed.

image:image.image:title: gemuendina_diagram600
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Based on the scale bar, this a surprisingly small specimen, full scale on a typical computer monitor.

image:image.image:title: fish_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on fish. This reflects a change from previous cladograms.

image:image.image:title: Lepisosteus_Semionotus_skulls588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Skulls of the extant gar (Lepisosteus) and its Late Triassic ancestor (Semionotus).

image:image.image:title: lepisosteus_semionotus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The extant gar (Lepisosteus) and its Late Triassic ancestor (Semionotus).

image:image.image:title: Triturus-sp.pes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Left to right: Original illustration from Wagner and Chiu 2001. Cleaned up and labeled. Placed on top of an in vivo pes with a phase shift movement of the metatarsals. Some toes are curled, so the graphic bones extend beyond the curl.Â

image:image.image:title: dory-on-a-branch588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The pterosaur Dorygnathus perching on a branch. Above the pes of Dorygnathus demonstrating the use of pedal digit 5 as a universal wrench (left), extending while the other four toes flexed around a branch of any diameter and (right) flexing with the other four toes. As in birds, perching requires bipedal balancing because the medially directed fingers have nothing to grasp.

image:image.image:title: ornithischia-2019-cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ornithischia from Ning et al. Overlay lists missing taxa and outgroups from the LRT (see Fig. 2).

image:image.image:title: aetosaurus-ticinosuchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Hemiprotosuhus image from Desojo and Ezccura 2016. Colors added. This taxon is derived from Ticinosuchus, basal to aetosaurs.

image:image.image:title: protosuchus-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Protosuchus skull. The high cranium and low triangular rostrum evidently made Bonaparte 1969 consider Hemiprotosuchus similar enough to Protosuchus.

image:image.image:title: Hemiprotosuchus-leali-PVL-3829_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Hemiprotosuchus leali skull from Desojo and Ezcurra, nests with Decuriasuchus in the LRT. The variation within this clade is increased with this nesting.

image:image.image:title: gnathovorax_insitu72
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Gnathovorax in situ from Pacheco et al. 2019. Green bones belong to other taxa.

image:image.image:title: Gnathovorax-original-cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cladogram from Pacheco et al. 2019. Colors added over the nodes to show where taxa nest in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Gnathovorax_compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Gnathovorax compared to Herrerasaurus, PVL 4597 and Decuriasuchus.

image:image.image:title: Plectocretacicus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Tiny Plectocretacicus now nests at the closest sister to the giant oarfish, Regalecus (Figs. 2, 3). Plectocretacicus retains all the stickleback spines found in the freshwater stickleback, Gasterosteous. Skull bones are revised here from their earlier interpretation. The quadrate is taphonomically too far forward in this figure. It should articulate at the posterior of the mandible.

image:image.image:title: regalecus.glesne.skull588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 2. Skull of the giant oarfish (Regalecus glesne). Note similarities to Plectocretacicus in figure 1.

image:image.image:title: Gracilisuchus2-588
image:image.image:caption: Addendum figure. This is a better rendition of the new hindquarters of the PVL specimen. Apologies for any earlier inaccuracies. Thanks to M. Mortimer for pointing out I had mistaken a right ischium for a left one and tarsal inaccuracies. If there are further problems, please let me know, or contact Romer.

image:image.image:title: gracilisuchus-pvl4597-5881
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Gracilisuchus holotype and the new specimen, PVL 4597 compared to scale. The PVL specimen is re-reconstructed below in the addendum image, so do not . There are six specimens of Gracilisuchus. PULR 08 appears to have no pedal 5 phalanges, distinct from the PVL specimen which has distinct metatarsal lengths.

image:image.image:title: PVL-4597
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. A subset of the large reptile tree including the new PVL specimen and Gracilisuchus, both highlighted.

image:image.image:title: Gracilisuchus-PVL4597-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Gracilisuchus holotype and the new specimen, PVL 4597compared.

image:image.image:title: Gracilisuchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Gracilisuchus revised with the subtraction of limbs and tail. Â Romer added limbs and a tail that are erased here.

image:image.image:title: Gracilisuchus_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Gracilisuchus holotype, PULR 08, in situ, both sides, plus chimaera created by Lecuona, Diego and Pol 2017 with the addition of PVL 4597, an unrelated taxon in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: gracilisuchus_pes_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The hind limb in question missing from Gracilisuchus and wrongly attributed by Lecuona, Desojo and Pol 2017 to Tropidosuchus.

image:image.image:title: gracilisuchus-MCZ4116
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. MCZ 4116 a short-faced Gracilisuchus compared to the holotype with a longer face.

image:image.image:title: gracilisuchus-crocodiliforms
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Figure 18 from Lecuona et al. 2017 with colors and reconstructions added. Here the giant, derived CM 73373 specimen nests basal to Hesperosuchus and taxa leading to Crocodiliformes. The LRT (subset Fig. 6) does not recover this topology.

image:image.image:title: gracilisuchus-archosauriformes-cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Figure 17 from Lecuona et al. 2017 with colors added to taxa that are not eu-archosauriforms in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: gracilisuchus-postcrania-Fig19cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. This is Figure 19 from Lecuona et al. 2017. All taxa are archosaurs in the Lecuona et al. cladogram. Red taxa are not archosaurs in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Triassic-Cretaceous_mammals588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Select basal cynodonts and mammals set chronologically. The divergence times for placentals (Eutheria), marsupials (Metatheria) and monotremes (Mammalia) are estimated here.

image:image.image:title: notopterus.588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Perleidus shares many traits with the extant knife fish, Notopterus, a taxon not mentioned in the abstract.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Perleidus woodwardi in situ and with skull reconstructed.

image:image.image:title: oxyaena588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Oxyaena, a traditional creodont. This is a cat-like member of the carnivorous Marsupialia.

image:image.image:title: mesenosaurus_recon588

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. ?Mesenosaurus efremovi, left and right sides from Maho et al. 2019. Colors added using DGS techniques.

image:image.image:title: sinodeophys_skull_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Reconstruced skull of Sinodelphys based on DGS methods. This is very close to Brasilitherium.

image:image.image:title: sinodelphys_manus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Manus of Sinodelphys as originally reconstructed. Flipping the hand, as in the revised image, more closely matches sister taxa with digits 3 and 4 the longest.

image:image.image:title: sinodelphys_skull_insitu
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Skull and forelimbs of Sinodelphys in situ. Arrow shows the displacement of the entire hand that otherwise appears to be lost beyond the matrix. How fortuitous!

image:image.image:title: sinodelphys_skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Sinodelphys skeleton in situ with select bones colored using DGS.

image:image.image:title: crocs_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal archosaurs and their immediate ancestors.

image:image.image:title: PVL4597skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The skull of PVL 4597 in several views from the 2013 PhD thesis of A. Leucona. Colors added.

image:image.image:title: fingers_and_toes_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Graphing the presence of fingers and toes in basal tetrapods, updated today with the addition of 4 digits in Panderichthys.

image:image.image:title: manus_LRT588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Forelimb of several basal tetrapods rearranged to more closely fit the LRT. Four fingers turns out to be the primitive number.Â Five is a recent mutation. Six was a short-lived experiment in Tulerpeton.

image:image.image:title: utegenia_diagram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Utegenia diagram showing five fingers on each hand. This is the most primitive taxon in our lineage to have all five.

image:image.image:title: Panderichthys_digits588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Boisert et al. 2008, colors added. This is their ordering for the evolution of manual digits. Compare to figure 2.

image:image.image:title: eoconodon_compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Eoconodon was either a mesonychid like Mesonyx, or a pre-tenrec mesonychid-mimic like Sinonyx.

image:image.image:title: didelphodon-diagram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Didelphodon from Wilson et al. 2016 had a 12 cm long skull.

image:image.image:title: earliest_paleocene588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Lyson et al. 2019 showing skulls of increasing size following the KPgE.

image:image.image:title: fingers_and_toes_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal tetrapods and the origin of fingers and toes.

image:image.image:title: BasalTetrapods588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT focusing on the basal tetrapods including Trypanognathus.

image:image.image:title: Trypanognathus-overall588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Trypanognathus in situ, colorized to bring out ribs and limbs.

image:image.image:title: jaw_becomes_ear
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Liaoconodon is a pre-mammal without a mammalian jaw joint (squamosal-dentary). Original art one frame one. Replacement art on frame two. Arrow points to jaw joint. For some reason teeth were omitted from the modern mammal jaw. Nature editor Hentry Gee and author John Pickrell should have noticed this.

image:image.image:title: parmastega-skull-4views588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Parmastega compared to scale with Acanthostega and Ventastega.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Basal vertebrates in the lineage of reptiles, part 3.

image:image.image:title: tetrapod_genesis2
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Basal vertebrates in the lineage of reptiles, part 2.

image:image.image:title: tetrapod_genesis1
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Basal vertebrates in the lineage of reptiles, part 1.

image:image.image:title: long-et-al-cladogram368
image:image.image:caption: From Long et al. 2018, their cladogram of taxa in the transition from fins to feet.

image:image.image:title: fish-tetrapod_Clack2009588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Modified from Clack 2009 showing the taxa in the transition from fins to feet.

image:image.image:title: onychodus_ischnacanthus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Onychodus and Ischnacanthus share enough traits to make them sisters, apart from Brachyacanthus + Pteronisculus.

image:image.image:title: pteronisculus_and_brachyacanthus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Surprising homologies in Pteronisculus and Brachyacanthus indicate a close relationship, despite the spiny fins.

image:image.image:title: eagle_ray_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Spotted eagle ray skull shows the anterior portions of the pectoral fins jointed medially to create a digging snout.

image:image.image:title: Squatina-dumeril-ventral588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 7. Squatina in ventral view showing the anterior processes of the pectoral fin that develop into a rostrum in Aetobatus and shift the gill slits ventrally.

image:image.image:title: squatina-squatina-lateral-invivo588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Squatina in vivo, lateral view. The large pectoral and pelvic fins give Squatina a broad, ray-like appearance in dorsal view.

image:image.image:title: Squatina-guggenheim_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Squatina skull. Note the gill bars framing the mouth. These are modified in Aetobatus into a digging snout.

image:image.image:title: squatina_skull588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 2. Squatina skull in two lateral views, with open and closed jaws. Even at this early stage some bones found in higher vertebrates can be identified here. Teeth appear here for the first time.

image:image.image:title: rays_cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal vertebrates. Purple taxa are traditional rays, here shown to be convergent in their morphology.

image:image.image:title: Aetobatus_ocellatus588invivo
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The spotted eagle ray, Aetobatus in vivo.

image:image.image:title: rhincodon_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Manta compared to Thelodus and Rhincodon. All three have a terminal mouth essentially straight across, between the lateral eyes.

image:image.image:title: dorygnathus-variety588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. Click to enlarge. The descendants of Sordes in the Dorygnathus clade and their two clades of pterodactyloid-grade descendants.

image:image.image:title: Mystacina-tuberculata_skull_lat588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Mystacina skull from Digimorph.org and colorized here.

image:image.image:title: Mystacina-tuberculata-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skeleton of Mystacina tuberculata from Digimorph.org and used with permission. The large head size is a derived trait.

image:image.image:title: bats_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on bats and kin including Mystacina.

image:image.image:title: hyrax-elephant588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. The small furry hyrax is in the lineage of the large naked elephant, analogous to small feathery theropods and large naked theropods. The fingers and incisors already show similarities here.

image:image.image:title: tyrannosaurus-feathers
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Tyrannosaurus (without feathers) to scale and directly compared to Zhenyuanlong (with feathers).

image:image.image:title: tyrannosaurus-yutyrannus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Late Cretaceous Tyrannosaurus, which has scales, to scale with Early Cretaceous allosaurid, Yutyrannus, which has filaments.

image:image.image:title: Pholidophorus_fins588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Pholidophorus ghosted to highlight the fins.

image:image.image:title: cladoselache_overall
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Classic reconstruction of Cladoselache, a shark-like taxon basal to higher sharks and rays.

image:image.image:title: placoderm_lobefin_transition588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The placoderm/catfish to spiny shark/lobe fin transition. We need more Silurian taxa, but here's how the LRT recovers it.

image:image.image:title: acanthodii_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Subset of the LRT with the addition of Brachyacanthus.

image:image.image:title: xiphactinus_fin-spines588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 3. Xiphactinus pectoral fins are not fragile ray-fins, but are compressed to form something similar to the spine-like fins seen in Brachyachanthus (Fig. 1)

image:image.image:title: brachyacanthus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Brachyacanthus is a tiny acanthodian fish with division, rather than fusion, of the facial bones. These correspond to those of sister taxa in the LRT. You might call it guesswork. You might call it pattern recognition.

image:image.image:title: spinysharks_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on the clade of free-swimming lobefin fish that gave rise to acanthodians (spiny sharks) and ray fin fish.

image:image.image:title: ischnacanthus_head588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Ischnacanthus skull in situ and reconstructed. Note the remnants of ray fins posterior to the large pectoral spine.

image:image.image:title: ischnacanthus_overall588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ischnacanthus in situ. Note the tail is right side up here, the torso is ventrally exposed and the skull is upside down (relative to the tail). So this fossil is twisted.

image:image.image:title: basal_tetrapods588may
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal tetrapods. Here demonstrated or presumed air-breathing is shown in cyan. Loss of this ability should be expected in free-swimming clade members. Fingers in light green.

image:image.image:title: tylosurus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Tylosurus, the needlefish, in several views. This taxon links swordfish to flying fish and links this clade to barracudas + pikes and to garfish (Lepisosteus).

image:image.image:title: flyingfish_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal vertebrates (fish) with the addition of Tylosurus, the needlefish.

image:image.image:title: Exocoetus_volitans588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Flying fish (Exocoetus volitans) line drawing.

image:image.image:title: exocoetus-volitans588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Flying fish (Exocoetus) skull.

image:image.image:title: cheirolepis_alone588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Cheirolepis, a Middle Devonian ancestor to the viperfish.

image:image.image:title: viperfish_teeth588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Viperfish posed as if biting its prey attracted to its first dorsal fin lure.

image:image.image:title: viperfish_Chauliodus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Chauliodus, the viperfish, in vivo.

image:image.image:title: chauliodus_diagram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Chauliodus diagram from Gregory 1938. Note the convergent loss of cheek bones in this Cheirolepis clade member.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cladogram from Klembara et al. 2019. Green shows reptile taxa in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Kadimakara_fossils588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. What remains of Kadimakara, above, and the referred specimen, below.

image:image.image:title: gogonasus_skull588

image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. Apparently overlooked by all eight authors, Ferrodraco has a gracile post-crania compared to its rostrum.

image:image.image:title: nurhachius2_recon588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 2. New Nurhachius reconstruction. Sorry,Riley, no grin. The tiny, slit-like nostril and anterior extensions of the nasal and jugal following it are shown here.

image:image.image:title: nurhachius2-in-situ588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. New Nurhachius skull in situ. Bone colors added using DGS methods.Â BPMC-0204

image:image.image:title: euypharynx-evolution588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The ancestry of Eurypharynx extends to moray eels and rhizodontid lobe fins, like Onychodus (Fig. 1)

image:image.image:title: onychodus-overall-compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The tail tip is added to Onychodus and a body is added based on phylogenetic bracketing. Interesting comparing the much larger body of Gymnothorax given the relatively similar-sized skulls in Onychodus and Gymnothorax.

image:image.image:title: Aphanopus_carbo588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Meter-long Aphanopus, the black scabbard fish, has a long, eel-like torso tipped with a tiny diphycercal tail.

image:image.image:title: arboroharamiya_torso_hg-m018-a-insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The paratype specimen of Arboroharamiya HG-M018, in situ. DGS color tracing added. The skull is in poor shape.

image:image.image:title: arborohyaramiya_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT nesting Arboroharamiya with Carpolestes within Rodentia

image:image.image:title: arborharamyia_hg-m017-a_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The holotype specimen of Arboroharamiya HG-M017 in situ with DGS tracings added.

image:image.image:title: arborharamiya_hg-m017-postdentary
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Images from Han et al. Color and white labels added. Here the malleus, incus and stapes have reverted to their pre-mammal states and configurations. Note the quadrate is in contact with the articular, as in pre-mammals as the dentary and squamosal become a sliding joint, carried by larger jaw muscles. Also note the various ectotympanic bones (yellow) also present, typical of Theria.

image:image.image:title: arboroharamiya-cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Han et al. 2017, a cladogram that nests Arboroharamiya close to Xianshou and Shenshou. Colors added to showing the shuffling of various clades in the LRT. Cyan = Eutheria. Red = Metatheria. Yellow = Prototheria. Gray = Trithelodontia. White are untested or basal cynodonts.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Coccocephalichthys (formerly Coccocephalus) is a Late Carboniferous transitional taxon between Devonian Strunius and Cretaceous Saurichthys.

image:image.image:title: Anhinga_anhinga_skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Anhinga anhinga skeleton. Note the large number of cervical vertebrae. These enable the snake-like darting of the sharp skull while attacking prey underwater.

image:image.image:title: gavia_stellata_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Skull of the common loon (Gavia stellata) showing the primitive state, with large external nares and antorbital fenestra.

image:image.image:title: anhinga_rufa_skull
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull of Anhinga rufa, an Old World relative of the New World Anhinga anhinga. Note the expansion of the maxilla (or overlying horny tissue) nearly obscuring the naris and antorbital fenestra. Compare to the loon in figure 3.

image:image.image:title: metriorhynchus-lateral588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Several Jurassic sea crocs, apparently derived from Late Triassic Dyoplax.

image:image.image:title: Dyoplax_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Dyoplax arenaceus Fraas 1867 is a mold fossil recently considered to be a sphenosuchian crocodylomorph. Here it nests as a basal metriorhynchid (sea crocodile) in the Late Triassic.

image:image.image:title: Dyoplax2013-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Added 08/09/19 from Maisch et al. 2013. DGS sutures do not match sutures found by Maisch et al. (drawing) Hypothetical missing parts based on phylogenetic bracketing ghosted on in color

image:image.image:title: Quetz_wingspan_compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Quetzalcoatlus in dorsal view compared to two much smaller azhdarchids from the Solnhofen formation, JME-Sos 2428, a flightless pterosaur, and BDPG 1911 I 31, a volant pterosaur. The wingspan of Quetzalcoatlus does not match that of the much smaller azhdarchid, so perhaps the giant was unable to fly. At least, this is the evidence for flightlessness.

image:image.image:title: Keresdrakon_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The larger bits and pieces of Keresdrakon. The bone is like bone, clearly distinct from the matrix.

image:image.image:title: anole on display
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Nearly bipedal anole (Anolis) and its gular sac on display.

image:image.image:title: Nesbitt_cladogram8
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Midpoint cladogram reduced and rescored from Nesbitt et al. 2017. The higher number of MPTs happens when traits are rescored incompletely.

image:image.image:title: nesbitt12
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Reduced and rescored cladogram from Nesbitt et al. 2017. This cladogram now greatly resembles the LRT.

image:image.image:title: postosuchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Postosuchus to scale with Hesperosuchus (Fig. 2).

image:image.image:title: Pterorhynchus=dewlap
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Pterorhynchus dewlap. Is this a feathery beard? Has it been torn off of another part of the body? Does it even belong to this pterosaur?

image:image.image:title: pterorhynchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Pterorhynchus with soft tissue.

image:image.image:title: Pterorhynchus2
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Animated GIF of Pterorhynchus taken in UV light with overlays and tracings. The 'wattle' appears to have two major partsÂ and the lower part appears to be made of at least three feathery ribbons or plumes.

image:image.image:title: pterorhynchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Pterorhynchus with soft tissue.

image:image.image:title: pterorhynchus_uv
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Pterorhynchus under UV light. Given that no sisters have such a dewlap, this now looks like a displaced wing membrane, as in Sordes.

image:image.image:title: Speothos_venaticus_skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Speothos, the South American bush dog, skeleton and in vivo.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Speothos is the living bush dog from South America.

image:image.image:title: theory and practice
image:image.image:caption: FIgure x. From the Don Prothero lab. I think we've ALL been saying this for a long time.

image:image.image:title: pseudotherium-cladogram588
