image:image.image:title: pseudotherium-skull.588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Pseudotherium from Wallace, Martinez and Rowe 2019, eyeball, premaxilla and mandible added here.

image:image.image:title: aetosaur_evolution
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. How the LRT nests three tested aetosaurs, arising from Ticinosuchus. Nesbitt xxxx wondered if the distinctive triangular premaxilla was a lacrimal.

image:image.image:title: revueltosaurus_evolution
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. How the LRT nests Revueltosaurus, as a basal euparkeriid, between Tasmaniosaurus and Fugusuchus. Overall they all resemble one another.

image:image.image:title: flicker_tongue
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. The woodpecker tongue and hyoid and how it works to extend the tongue into wood to extract burrowing insects.

image:image.image:title: melanerpes_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Skull of the woodpecker, Melanerpes.

image:image.image:title: sittacarolinensis_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Sitta the nuthatch skull and in vivo. Pecking insects from tree bark is the first stage in drilling tree bark for insects.

image:image.image:title: Scleromochlus skeleton Witton 2013
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Scleromochlus by Witton 2013, via Benton 1999. Now promoted as a fuzzy pterosaur precursor.

image:image.image:title: pholidogaster-zalchemie_tracks588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Early Carboniferous limbed osteolepid, Pholidogaster, compared to Middle Devonian Zalchemie tracks to scale.

image:image.image:title: 3_manta_skeletons588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Three views of the skeleton of Manta, colors added. Green represents the maxilla. Note the terminal mouth, distinct from other rays, skates and guitarfish. The pectoral fins do not reach the orbit. The cephalic fins are highly modified maxillae, still gathering food. Note the attachment to the quadrate. The premaxilla extends across the mouth.

image:image.image:title: cownose-ray-feeding588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cownose ray feeding by dropping their cephalic lobes to increase the suction on their oyster prey.

image:image.image:title: cownose_cephalic_lobes
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cownose ray lobes open and close like flaps.

image:image.image:title: rhinobatos_jaw250
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Rhinobatus jaw mechanism animation. This is how skates and rays eat, distinct from the Thelodus/ whale shark/ manta ray method of ram feeding.

image:image.image:title: rhinobatos_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Guitarfish (Rhinobatos) skull. Colors, eyeballs and spiracles added.

image:image.image:title: giants_manta588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The largest manta ray to scale with humans.

image:image.image:title: Rhinobatus_lentiginosus_and_Rhina588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Rhinobatos, the guitarfish, and Rhina the bowhead guitarfish, are transitional to skates and rays, but not mantas. Note the ventral mouth and pectoral fins extending anterior to the orbits.

image:image.image:title: remora_hatchling_spines
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. From Britz and Johnson 2012 showing a hatchling remora, focusing on the tiny spines in the cervical region that ultimately become the adhesion disc.

image:image.image:title: remora-head588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The head of a remora showing in three views of the adhesion disc that make this fish the one and only 'shark-sucker.'

image:image.image:title: cobia-and-whale-shark-588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 7. Cobia and remora surrounding a whale shark. Cobia have to work harder to keep up. Remora rather easily hitches a ride instead.

image:image.image:title: remora_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Skull of Remora with a large adhesion disc extending forward to the premaxilla.

image:image.image:title: opisthomyzon_skull_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. The skull of Opisthomyzon in situ and reconstructed. Note the small adhesion disk at the back of the skull, essentially replacing the postparietals.

image:image.image:title: opisthomyzon-insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The early Oligocene pre-remora, Opisthomyzon, with a small adhesion disc at the back of the flat skull.

image:image.image:title: remora-invivo588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. A remora attached to a much larger shark with an adhesion disc atop its head. Gone are the 6 to 9 dorsal spines.

image:image.image:title: Rachycentron_canadum_588invivo
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. The remora starts here: with the cobia (Rachycentron). Note the overall resemblance, lacking an adhesion disc. Instead six to nine tiny spine-hooks appear where an anterior dorsal fin appears on other fish.

image:image.image:title: cheirodus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Mimipiscis the Devonian palaeoniscid, is a sister to Amphicentrum, a Carboniferous triggerfish mimic in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Eliomys_quercinus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Eliomys, the dormouse.

image:image.image:title: glires_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on Glires and subclades within.

image:image.image:title: pseudictops-teeth
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1a. Pseudictops anterior teeth.

image:image.image:title: leptictis-insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Leptictis, an early Oligocene elephant shrew.

image:image.image:title: pseudictops-skull_restoration588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Pseudictops lophiodon compared to the slightly larger Siamotherium.

image:image.image:title: sea_horse_evolution_fishes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Stickleback to sea horse evolution through pipefish. Sticklebacks have some of the body armor that overall encases and stiffens sea horses and sea dragons like Hippocampus and two species of Phyllopteryx. The ghost pipeish Solenostomus, is distinct from the more slender, elongate types of pipefish.

image:image.image:title: regalecus.glesne.skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Skull of the giant oarfish, Regalecus glesne. Note the mouth opens like a drawbridge with a dorsal premaxilla. The pectoral and pelvic girdles are merged. The elaborate postparietals anchor the cranial frill. Not sure about the 'second quadrate'. I could find no homolog for that bone.

image:image.image:title: Regalecus_giant_oarfish588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The giant oarfish, Regalecus glesne, to scale with a couple of swimmers. Sometimes it swims vertically, often at great depths.

image:image.image:title: gnathonemus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Gnathonemus, the elephant fish, for obvious reasons, has been traditionally considered a sister to Osteoglossum. Here it nests with Hippocampus, the seahorse. Image from Gregory 1938.

image:image.image:title: fish_cladogram_seahorse588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal vertebrates (fish).

image:image.image:title: seahorse_evolution588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Most of the bones of the tetrapod skull are also found in sea horses with some odd changes, like the placement of the quadrate well anterior to the orbit. Hippocampus illustration from Franz-Odendaal and Adriaens 2014. Not the parasphenoid passing midway through the orbit, while in tetrapods the orbit is typically raised above this anteriorly-directed splint-like bone arising from the basicranium. Everything below it is mouth cavity.

image:image.image:title: Lepisosteus_skulll588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Skull of Lepisosteus in dorsal and lateral views. Several cheek bones were lost earlier and refilled here creating another solid cheek without a lateral temporal fenestra

image:image.image:title: lepidosteus588xray
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The long nose gar, Lepisosteus, in X-ray.

image:image.image:title: basal-bony-fish-wikipedia588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Wikipedia, a subset from a traditional cladogram of fish nesting gars with bowfins. The LRT does not support that hypothesis of relationships.

image:image.image:title: fish_cladogram588naris
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal vertebrates. Colors indicate various naris configurations. Some palates are not known.

image:image.image:title: OriginofChoana-Janvier588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Janvier 2015, evolution of the internal naris (choana) from primitive dual external nares.

image:image.image:title: fish_cladogram_fast_slow_bottom588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal vertebrates (fish) colorized according to speed/metabolism.

image:image.image:title: Pholidophorus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Pholidophorus in situ and two skulls attributed to this genus. Compare the one on the left to figure 2. No tested fish in the LRT is closer to Robustichthys than Pholidophorus.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Skull of Robustichthys. Compare to Pholidophorus in figure 3.

image:image.image:title: vjushkovia588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Vjushkovia = Youngosuchus. This largely overlooked taxon is an erythrosuchid descendant that was ancestral to the Rauisuchia, the Aetosauria and the Archosauria.Â

image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Cladogram from wiki/Holostei showing traditional interrelationships among other vertebrate taxa.

image:image.image:title: holosteans-gars-bowfins
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Taxa that make up the traditional but invalidated clade, Holostei include Lepisosteiformes, Ammiformes and the Triassic Polidophorus. They appear in distinct clades in the LRT. Image from Encyclopedia Brittanica needs to be updated.

image:image.image:title: When_Whales_Walked_Paris_pakicetus_t600
image:image.image:caption: At the Museum of Natural History in Paris, Dr. Christian De Muizon shows off the complete reconstruction of the Pakicetus skeleton, surprisingly an ancient relative of modern day whales.

image:image.image:title: YPM-VP-57103_cf_Dromicosuchus

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Microdocodon throat region. Are those bones hyoids or fingers? If hyoids, then where are the fingers? Note the displaced radius (olive green) Â reaching toward the throat. Only impressions of once present fingers are present on the right limb.

image:image.image:title: hesperornithoides_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Cladogram published by Hartman et al. 2019, colors added to more or less match those in the subset of the LRT (Fig. 4), a distinctly different topology. Here birds and troodontids/anchirornithids are polypheletic.

image:image.image:title: theropod-bird-transition588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT focusing on the theropod-bird transition, distinctly different than in Hartman et al. 2019. Here in a fully resolved cladogram, birds and anchiornithids are monophyletic. Taxon inclusion resolves cladistic issues raised by Hartman et al.

image:image.image:title: sinusonasus-recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Published reconstruction of Hesperornithes from Hartman et al. 2019, to scale with Caihong, a similar, though smaller, taxon and Sinusonasus, another sister based on very few bones, but look at that canine fang!

image:image.image:title: Hesperornithoides-miessleri_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Tentative restoration of the skull of Hesperornithes alongside to scale skull of Caihong. The maxillae are similar and both have a distinct fang.

image:image.image:title: electrophorus_skull
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Skull of the electric eel (Electrophorus) distinct from the moray eel (Fig. 4) and European eel (Fig. 2).

image:image.image:title: Sphyraena_barracuda_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The skull of the barracuda (genus: Sphyraena) with bones identified with colors.

image:image.image:title: Anguilla_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. The skull of Anguilla from Gregory 1936, with bones colored here and matched to an invivo photo. This is a revised illustration.

image:image.image:title: Anguilla_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The skull of Anguilla from xx, with bones colored here and matched to an invivo photo.

image:image.image:title: Anguilla_anguilla_invivo588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The European eel, Anguilla anguilla in vivo.

image:image.image:title: fish_cladogram_tuna588

image:image.image:title: tuna_thunnus_skull2
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Thunnus, the tuna, nests with some of the most basal bony fish, like Strunius and Pholidophorus.

image:image.image:title: tuna_skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Thunnus, the tuna, skeleton and skin. More primitive than traditional cladograms recover it.

image:image.image:title: saurichthys588

image:image.image:title: mola-larvae588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Mola larvae ontogeny. The caudal fin appears at first, then disappears as the dorsal and anal fin ossify and the body deepens.

image:image.image:title: SeriolaRivolianaUSNM588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Seriola rivoliana is the high fin Amberjack is basal to gobies and tetraodontiformes.

image:image.image:title: periophthalmus.skull588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 2. The mudskipper (genus: Periophthalmus) is close to Diodon in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Diodon-pufferfish588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Diodon the pufferfish offers a problem. Are those facial spines circumorbital bones? Ore are they novel dermal ossifications?

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Psarolepis and its place in the origin of bony ray fin fish, based on Yu 1998. The LRT refutes this cladogram.

image:image.image:title: chologaster_blind_cave_fish588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Forbesichthys an apparent sister taxon to Electrophorus along with other sisters to the blind cave fish, Typhlichthys subterraneus. When I find skull material for Forbesichthys, I will enter it in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: lophius-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The flexible Lophius skull can flatten or expand, sucking in small fish and other prey items. The prefrontal and most cheek bones are missing here. If those are vomers, those are the largest teeth in the jaws. Otherwise the premaxillae have two rows of teeth.

image:image.image:title: lophius_invivo588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Lophius in vivo. The pelvic fins are hidden from view beneath the large pectoral fins. So Lophius is all mouth and tail. Inset shows a larva/hatchling not to scale.

image:image.image:title: electrophorus_overall588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Electrophorus, the electric eel, in vivo.

image:image.image:title: mola_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Mola mola is a relative of Diodon in the LRT. It has no circumorbital bones, but as a hatchling has pufferfish proportions and spines.

image:image.image:title: teleost_cladogram
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 4. Teleost (bony fish) cladogram. Diodon nests with Mola here.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Thylacosmilus compared to Vincelestes separated by tens of millions of years. The both have maxillae conjoined dorsally to house the large canines.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Synodontis in vivo with skeleton added in lateral view. The rotation of the mouth to the ventral surface is a derived trait not seen in the more primitive catfish.

image:image.image:title: basal_vertebrates4
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Basal vertebrates in the LRT closest to the lineage that gave rise to tetrapods and ultimately humans. This is a slow-moving, low-slung, flat-headed bunch. Swifter, rounder taxa, better suited to open waters are not on this list.

image:image.image:title: basal_tetrapods2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Basal tetrapods in the LRT closest to the lineage of humans. Note the continuation of slow, low-slung, flat-head taxa crawling onto land after crawling along the sea and lake bottoms.

image:image.image:title: plagiomene588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. What little is known of Plagiomene seems to agree with the North American adapid, Smilodectes, among tested taxa.

image:image.image:title: coccosteus-skull588

image:image.image:title: kenichthys_choana
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Kenichthys Images from Zhu and Ahlberg 2004, colors added. The authors made a convincing argument that Kenichthys represented a transitional taxon between Youngolepis and Eusthenopteron. Note the lack of vomer fangs and a distinctly different set of skull sutures in Kenichthys, which does not nest with Eusthenopteron in the LRT.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Chimaera monstrosa in vivo.

image:image.image:title: ratfish-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ratfish skull with 'bones' (actually precursor cartilage' colored and labeled.

image:image.image:title: sturgeon.pseudoscaphirhynchus588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 2. The small sturgeon Pseudoscahirhynchus skull in several views. Note the perforated rostrum (nasal) sensitive to prey hiding in mud. The mouth is reduced to a tiny sucking tube disconnected from the quadrate. Even so, this sturgeon nests with sharks in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: ambopteryx-forelimb588
image:image.image:caption: Figure x. Closeup of the Ambopteryx forelimb. Here the purported radius + ulna is only the radius after crushing with two quarters of the exposed radius crushed neatly in half giving the impression of a radius + ulna, exactly the same length and exactly the same width, and without any interosseum space, which never happens in birds.

image:image.image:title: Ambopteryx-longibrachium_overall588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Photos and black tracing from Wang et al. 2019. Colors added here. There is no styliform bone on either wing. That is a displaced ulna... again.

image:image.image:title: Basal_vertebrates_Chlamydoselachus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Subset of the LRT with the addition of Chlamydoselachus. The operculum is present on orange and red taxa.

image:image.image:title: Chlamydoselachus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Chlamydoselachus skull with colors added and in vivo.

image:image.image:title: Chlamydoselachus_Osteolepis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. It is worthwhile comparing the basal shark, Chlamydoselachus, to the basal rhipidistian, Osteolepis, just a few nodes away.

image:image.image:title: Chlamydoselachus-gills588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Ventral view of Chalmydoselachus showing two sets of gills: one retained by bony fish, the others retained by sharks and rays.

image:image.image:title: ambopteryx-yi_qi_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ambopteryx nests midway and is phylogenetically midway between the larger Yi and the smaller Scansoriopteryx. None of these taxa have an extra long bone in the arm.

image:image.image:title: pterosaur_evolution588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Invalid cladogram of the Pterosauria from Buchmann and Rodrigues 2019. Colors are clades confirmed by the LRT.

image:image.image:title: yeti track
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. 2019 yeti tracks found in Nepal and posted online.

image:image.image:title: TetrapodaMay2019_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure1. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal tetrapods, modified from earlier versions by adding taxa and re-scoring after better data was found.

image:image.image:title: Klobiodon_Witton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Mark Witton painting of Klobiodon, based on the mandible on the overlay. Note the dental mismatch, the rotation of the lateral digit to the medial border of invalid uropatagia fused medially beneath the tail following the invalidated Sordes model. Not a good way to start if attempting to pride oneself in scientific accuracy leading a blogpost on cranks. Copyright law permits criticism and science under Fair Usage in the USA and UK, if anyone is concerned.

image:image.image:title: Palaeothentes_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Not a marsupial, and not a shrew opossum, Palaeothentes nests in the LRT at the base of the Apatemys + Trogosus clade nest to the clade of living shrew opossums within Glires.

image:image.image:title: archaeopteryx.berlin.specimen588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Generic freehand Archaeopteryx (Berlin specimen) from Schwarz et al. 2019, retraced from Wellnhofer 2008 compared to bone-by-bone tracing for ReptileEvolution.com.

image:image.image:title: basal_tetrapods2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Basal tetrapods to scale. Yellow taxa are temnospondyls. Red taxa are reptilomorphs.

image:image.image:title: colosteus_osteolepis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Colosteus is covered with dermal skull bones and osteoderms. Those vestigial forelimbs are transitional to the limbless condition in Phlegethontia.

image:image.image:title: Plagiosuchus-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Plagiosuchus skull from Damiani et al. 2009, lateral view and colors added here.

image:image.image:title: Sclerothorax-holotype588

image:image.image:title: Sclerothorax-skull4views
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Sclerothorax skull in 4 views from Schoch et al. 2007, colors added. A second skull is shown in lateral view to match the elements and proportions of the dorsal view.

image:image.image:title: Sclerothorax-overall588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Images from Schoch et al. 2007 combining various specimens to create a Sclerothorax chimaera.

image:image.image:title: SclerothoraxNMKS118b588r
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. NMK-S118 and 117 specimens assigned to Sclerothorax. Colors added.

image:image.image:title: dvinia-prima588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Amalitskii 1922, Dvinia skull and mandible from various views.

image:image.image:title: therocephalian-reduction588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Cladogram from Brocklehurt 2019, colors added. Lycosuchus, listed as a basal therocephalian by Brocklehurst, also nests close to cynodonts in the TST. No gorgonopsids are shown here. Biarmosuchus is the outgroup taxon here, a more distant outgroup taxon in the TST.

image:image.image:title: carnivora_to_scale
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Carnivora to scale. Note: one branch does increase in size over time (ignoring toy poodles for the moment), while another branch, the one leading to Talpa the mole, shrinks in size.

image:image.image:title: eotitanosuchus_size_compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Gorgonopsids, therocephalians and cynodonts to scale.

image:image.image:title: dicynodonts
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Dicynodont ancestor skulls to scale, according to the LRT.

image:image.image:title: therapsida-anomodontia-LRT588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT highlighting the anomodontia and dicynodontia closer to the origin of the Therapsida.

image:image.image:title: Thliptosaurus_cladogram_Kammerer588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Cladogram of the anomodontia and dicynodontia from Kammerer 2019. Blue taxa are proximal outgroups.

image:image.image:title: patranomodon-postcrania588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1b. Patranomodon post-crania assembled.

image:image.image:title: patranomodon_skull588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. Patranomodon with bones colored here helped to rescuer the taxon. The original drawing omitted the septomaxilla and the anterior rostrum and mandible. Now it really does look more like a basal dicynodont.

image:image.image:title: dicynodonts
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The ancestry of dicynodonts includes Patranomodon and Galeops.

image:image.image:title: venjukoviamorphs
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Patranomodon and Galeops are sisters, both in the ancestry of dicynodonts and venjukoviamorphs.

image:image.image:title: lycosuchus_color588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Abdalodon nests with the many times larger therocephalian Lycosuchus in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Charassognathus-gracilis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Charassognathus does not share more traits with Abdalodon than other taxa, like Bauria and Promoschorhynchops in the TT.

image:image.image:title: lycosuchus_color588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Abdalodon nests with the many times larger therocephalian Lycosuchus in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Anteosaurus_abeli588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Anteosaurus abeli skull with right side grayed out and colors added.

image:image.image:title: anteosaurus_juvenile_compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Anteosaurus magnifies compared to the smaller and coeval BP/1/7074 specimen others considered a juvenile. Other more closely related specimens in the TT are also shown alongside BP/1/7074 specimen.

image:image.image:title: patranomodon_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. TST revised with new data on Patranomodon and sister taxa.

image:image.image:title: Hipposaurus-WB123_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Hipposaurus skull with colors applied and used to create reconstruction on the right. Note the squamosal is largely missing and splinters of bone fill the orbit. Here those splinters are used to recreate a standard squamosal for this clade.

image:image.image:title: anteosaurus_ontogeny_no
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Kruger et al. 2017 figure 21. provided "Ontogenetic changes in the skull of Anteosaurus; A. juvenile; B, intermediate sized; C, adult sized, redrawn from Kammerer 2011. Their figure 20 labeled the intermediate sized skull as Titanophoneus. So this is a phylogenetic series, not an ontogenetic one.

image:image.image:title: bp7074_parts
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. From Kruger 2014 the parts of BP/1/7074 colorized to show how the bones were 'disarticulated.' This is not disarticulation. This is breakage.

image:image.image:title: bp_1_7074_72
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The purported juvenile Anteosaurus skull, BP/1/7074 compared to he coeval Australosyodon.

image:image.image:title: reptilomorpha588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Members of the Reptilomorpha and their proximal outgroups illustrated to scale and in their phylogenetic order from top (primitive) to bottom (derived).

image:image.image:title: baphetids588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Ventastega nests with Crassigyrinus in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: largest_amphibians588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Click to enlarge. The largest amphibians of all time include Mastodonsaurus, Prionosuchus, Koolasuchus, Siderops, Crassigyrinus and the extant Andrias, the giant Chinese salamander.

image:image.image:title: Fins2Feet_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal tetrapods and showing those taxa with lobefins (fins) and those with fingers and toes (feet). Inbetween we have no data.

image:image.image:title: siderops588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Siderops in several views from Warren and Hutchinson 1983, colors added. The related giant Koolasuchus and small Gerrothorax are added for scale.

image:image.image:title: styxosaurus_animated588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Styxosaurus mandible animated.

image:image.image:title: styxosaurus_skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Styxosaurus skeleton as originally drawn and revised here.

image:image.image:title: styxosaurus_skull_historical588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The changing face of Styxosaurus from Welles 1890, Otero 2016 and colorized here.

image:image.image:title: styxosaurus-skull-KUVP-1301-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull of Styxosaurus (KUVP 1301) from Sachs, Lindgren and Kear 2018, colorized using DGS methods.

image:image.image:title: styxosaurus_paddles588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Styxosaurus paddles. Metcarpals (left) and Metatarsals (right) colored.

image:image.image:title: julio lacerda quetz and spider
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Incredibly gorgeous and evocative artwork, playing with light, mixing unrelated subjects wonderfully, the art of Julio Lacerda.

image:image.image:title: tricleidus.animation588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. GIF animation of Tricleidus skull demonstrating both the enormous gape and the filter-feeding teeth that permit water to be pushed out by a constricting throat sac.

image:image.image:title: majiashanosaurus-fremouwsaurus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The head of Palacrodon and the headless body of the Majiashanosaurus compared.

image:image.image:title: fremouwsaurus_placodonts588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. A comparison of basal placodonts to scale (and Paraplacodus reduced to one-third shows how Fremouwsaurus (Palacrodon) is transitional between the small spike-tooth ancestors like Palatodonta and Pappochelys and the pavement toothed Paraplacodus.

image:image.image:title: Peloneustes_philarchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Peloneustes fossil on display.

image:image.image:title: eusauropterygians_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT focusing on Eusauropterygians (pachypleurosaurs, nothosaurs, plesiosaurs and kin).

image:image.image:title: Simolestes_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Simolestes in several views and colorized using DGS methods compared to the elasmosaur, Libonectes.

image:image.image:title: bobosaurus_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Bobosaurus reconstructed to scale alongside the 3x smaller Corosaurus. Both share tall spines, small hands, a tiny ilium and other traits not found in sister taxa or pistosaurids.

image:image.image:title: Bobosaurus_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Bobosaurus in situ with colors added. See figure 2 for a reconstruction.

image:image.image:title: acostasaurus3views588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Acostasaurus skull from PÃ©rez and NoÃ© 2017, colors added.

image:image.image:title: dolichorhynchops_skull_diagram588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 2. Skull of Dolichorhynchops along with tracing by Carpenter and reconstruction by O'Keeefe, which seems overblown. Both workers overlooked the palatal extension of the premaxilla to the internal nares, as in other eusauropterygians.

image:image.image:title: dolichorhynchops_overall_vp-404_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The FHSM VP 404 specimen of Dolichorhynchops with modification to the pectoral girdle and hypothetical addition of chevrons. Gastalia are not shown, but were probably present based on phylogenetic bracketing.

image:image.image:title: elasmosaur-paper
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Elasmosaur on the rug. Note how all the elements hug the floor, including the neck. Imagine the real thing just above the floor, taking nips and bites from fish hiding wherever they can among the corals and sea detritus. The distal end of the long neck is quite flexible, as opposed to the rest of the neck and torso.

image:image.image:title: Aytonerpeton-skull-parts588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Aytonerpeton parts from Clack et al. 2016, restoration added.

image:image.image:title: Galulatherium-Paedotherium588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Galutatherium compared to the odd wombat, Paedotherium, a marsupial basal to Groeberia and Vintana in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: SimosaurusAnningasaura588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The sisters of Anningsaura, Simosaurus and Pistosaurus. These provide the only clues as to the post-crania of Anningsaura, of which only the first eight cervicals are known.

image:image.image:title: anningasaura588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Anningsaura (formerly Plesiosaurus macrocephalus) in three views. This specimen nests between Simosaurus and Pistosaurus (Fig. 2) at the base of the Pistosauria at the base of the Plesiosauria.

image:image.image:title: SimosaurusAnningsaura588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The sisters of Anningsaura, Simosaurus and Pistosaurus. These provide the only clues as to the post-crania of Anningsaura, of which only the first eight cervicals are known.

image:image.image:title: Anningasaura_engraving588b
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Anningasaura colorized from an old engraving. No other aquatic taxon has such bizarrely curved teeth. This taxon is closely related to Hauffiosaurus.

image:image.image:title: Hauffiosaurus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Hauffiosaurus skull in palatal view from Vincent 2011, colors added. Overlooked by Vincent, the premaxilla (yellow) contacts the internal naris

image:image.image:title: Pliosaurus-kevani-palate588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Pliosaurus kevani palate, from Benson et al. 2013, also has an overlooked premaxilla-internal naris contact.

image:image.image:title: Pachypleurosauria
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT. Here the clade Pachypleurosauria nests Anningsaura with Hauffiosaurus

image:image.image:title: Hauffiosaurus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Hauffiosaurus from Vincent 2011 with colors and reconstructions added.

image:image.image:title: kronosaurus_frontals588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Kronosaurus dorsal skull colorized from originals in McHenry 2009. Note the premaxilla/parietal contact.

image:image.image:title: FishTetrapodTransition-_Clack588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. The classic paradigm illustrating the fish-to-tetrapod transition from Clack 2009.

image:image.image:title: colosteids_recon2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Colosteus relatives according to the LRT scaled to a common skull length. Their sizes actually vary quite a bit, as noted by the different scale bars. Only Pholidogaster and Colosteus are taxa in common with traditional colosteid lists.

image:image.image:title: panderichthys-palate588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Panderichthys palates. Note the lateral line below the naris is not continuous, contra Lombard and Bolt.

image:image.image:title: deltaherpeton-insitu2_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Deltaherpeton in situ with inset showing location of naris and circumarial bones.

image:image.image:title: LargeReptileFamilyTree
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the large reptile tree. Classic colosteids are highlighted and connected by green lines.

image:image.image:title: greererpeton-compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Classic Collosteidae include Collosteus, Pholidogaster, Greererpeton and Deltaherpeton all to scale.

image:image.image:title: Laidleria-gracilis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Originally considered a trematosaur, and then an enigma, Laidleria gracilis nests at the base of the Dvinosauria/Plagiosauria in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: avimaia-2insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Avimaia in situ. Some bones were originally mislabeled. Here the egg is reconstructed with a more traditional egg shape.

image:image.image:title: enantiornithes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT focusing on the clade Enantiornithes and the nesting of Avimaia as a derived taxon within that clade.

image:image.image:title: Avimaia_Cathayornis_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Avimaia compared to Cathayornis to scale.

image:image.image:title: Peltobatrachus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Armored Peltobatrachus.Â

image:image.image:title: precocial-bird-2

DGS colors added and used in the reconstruction in figure 2. Not sure what those red highlighted items are at lower right. See figure 2b for skull details.Â

image:image.image:title: iberomesornis_MPCM-LH-26189_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Tiny Iberomesornis compared to scale with even tinier MPCM specimen. Note the tiny fingers. Two tibial lengths are presented since this data remains unknown. The tiny MPCM specimen does not appear to have juvenile proportions.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2b. Skull of MPCM specimen traced using DGS methods and reconstructed using the resulting color parts.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Subset of the LRT focusing on the Eusauropterygia, including Sachicasaurus.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Data for Nothosaurus for comparison with Sachicasaurus. The interclavicle could easily be lost.

image:image.image:title: sachicasaurus_flippers588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Sachisaurus pectoral girdle and flippers reconstructed with new identities provided here.

image:image.image:title: sachicasaurus_compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Sachicasaurus was the size of the pliosaurs, Kronosaurus and Brauchenia, but was related to Nothosaurus. This is the first known giant nothosaur.

image:image.image:title: Sachicasaurus-vitaeskull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Sachicasaurus skull from PÃ¡ramo-Fonseca et al. 2018, colors added.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ichthyostega after CT scanning (grey tones) here colored with light green 'skin' added and pectoral girdle pushed posteriorly to expose the neck.

image:image.image:title: basal_tetrapods588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on the basal (anamniote) Tetrapoda. The last week has been spent reexamining data and letting the taxa sort themselves out again. Please report any untenable relationships.

image:image.image:title: koilops_new588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Koliops with bones colorized, nests as a big-eyed, short-snouted, smaller, (perhaps juvenile?) relative of Tiktaalik and Spathicephalus in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: tiktaalik_insitu-dorsal2
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Revised skull sutures in Tiktaalik. Compare these to the sutures in Spathicephalus, figure 2.

image:image.image:title: convolosaurus_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Convolosaurus cladogram from Andrzejewski, Winkler and Jacobs 2019. Note the complete lack of consensus between the tree topology and figure 2.

image:image.image:title: phytodinosauria588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT focusing on the clade Phytodinosauria. Convolosaurus nests closer to the dome head dinosaurs, not the ornithopods.

image:image.image:title: Convolosaurus-skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. Convolosaurus from Andrzejewski, Winkler and Jacobs 2019, re built from a flock of juvenile specimens.

image:image.image:title: polar_bear_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Skull of Ursus maritimus, the polar bear. It's worthwhile noting the similarities and differences, which are more distinct than just the colors of their furry coats.

image:image.image:title: ursus-arctos-overall-drawing588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ursus arctos, the grizzly bear, nests with Ursus maritimus, the polar bear in the LRT, as expected.

image:image.image:title: spinosaurus_naris588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Diagram from Dal Sasso et al. 2005, colors and overlay added to show dorsal expansion of the maxilla to cover an elongate naris.

image:image.image:title: Spinosaurus_rostrum588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The rostrum of Spinosaurus. Note the maxilla rising to close off the elongate naris into a reduced anterior and posterior opening.

image:image.image:title: Pteranodon_size_compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Four Pteranodon specimens of increasing size. More robust arm bones are found in larger specimens. There is no reduction of distal wing elements.

image:image.image:title: Edmontosaurus-manus
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ornithopod manus. Here the hands of Dryosaurus, Camptosaurus, Iguanodon and Edmontosaurus are compared. Note the turquoise metatarsal homologies and the digit identifications based on that.

image:image.image:title: basal_theropods2019_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal theropods. Megaraptor and Murusraptor are highlighted.

image:image.image:title: sinocalliopteryx_Megaraptor588

image:image.image:title: Murusraptor_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Murusraptor compared with related taxa to scale.

image:image.image:title: Megaraptor_manus_compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Megaraptor also preserves a complete and distinct manus, here compared to Sinocalliopteryx, which also has a digit 4, and Suchomimus has a robust ungual 1.

image:image.image:title: Suchomimus588

image:image.image:title: Xiongguanlong-skull588

image:image.image:title: basal_theropods588

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Scale bars seem to be amiss here, but these are the bones and scale bars from the MUCPv 595 specimen of the skull of Megaraptor.

image:image.image:title: rhomaleosaurus_cramptoni_dorsal588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Two species attributed to the genus Rhomaleosaurus.

image:image.image:title: pineal588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Click to enlarge. This is the complete LRT highlighting the distribution of the pineal opening.

image:image.image:title: fish-brain-pineal588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Pineal body in a primitive jawless fish, like the lamprey.

image:image.image:title: Sharovipteryx_forelimb588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Sharovipteryx forelimb with digit 4 extended and flexed/folded. Note the large, deep unguals that appear to be useful, not vestigial.

image:image.image:title: sharovipteryx_pes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Sharovipteryx pes in dorsal and digit 4 in lateral view.

image:image.image:title: draco-sharovipteryx_on-tree-profile588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Draco and Sharovipteryx bipedally on tree trunk, flapping its tiny arms. Hatchling Sharovipteryx between them.

image:image.image:title: draco_sharovipteryx588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Sharovipteryx alongside a photo of Draco volans. Both lepidosaurs had sprawling limbs, a long fifth toe, attenuated tail, extrademal membranes and dorsal ribs that flatten and widen its torso.

image:image.image:title: Spring_Hare_(Pedetes_capensis)588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The spring hare (Pedetes) nests with the jerboa (Allactaga) in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Pedetes_Allactaga_skeletons588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skeletons of Pedetes and Allactaga to scale.

image:image.image:title: Palaechthon_compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Palaechthon compared to outgroup, Vulpavus, and sister, Cynocephalus using drawings from Kay and Cartmill 1974. Colors added.

image:image.image:title: rabbit_ancestors588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The Lagomorpha clade with the addition of Henkelotherium.

image:image.image:title: nambaroo7recon_leg588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 4. Nambaroo hind limb reconstructed and compared to the Macropus kangaroo pes. Note: Nambaroo enlarges pedal digit 4, whereas Macropus enlarges digit 3. Remarkable convergence.

image:image.image:title: henkelotherium_recon2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Henkelotherium reconstructed from DGS tracings in figure 1. Note the tiny manus and large pes, traits that continue into extant rabbits.

image:image.image:title: henkelotherium_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Henkelotherium, a traditional pantothere, nests as a Late Jurassic pre-rabbit in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: tadarida_invivo_skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Tadarida, the Mexican free-tailed bat, from Digimorph.org and used with permission. Colors added.

image:image.image:title: apatemys_skull_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Apatemys skull in situ and reconstructed shares several similar traits with the extant striped opossum, Dactylopsila, including a squirrel-like size, elongate fingers and similar teeth.

image:image.image:title: basal_marsupials588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT showing the nesting of Dactylopsila, the striped opossum.

image:image.image:title: MacroBESSC111-Cosesaurus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The BES SC111 specimen attributed to Macrocnemus compared to Cosesaurus, the taxon transitional to pterosaurs. See text for detais.

image:image.image:title: Iguana-toes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Green iguana demonstrating the curling of pedal digit 5 in tendril-toed arboreal lepidosaurs, as hypothesized in the BES SC111 specimen and pterosaurs.

image:image.image:title: MacrocnemusBES-SC111pelvis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. BES SC111 pelvic region. Colors correspond to those in figure 1. Note the tiny blue prepubes.

image:image.image:title: MacrocnemusBES-SC111pecs
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. BES SC111 pectoral region. Colors correspond to figure 1.

image:image.image:title: animated_size_comparison799
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Click to enlarge. Pteranodon scene from Prehistoric Life video from Dane Pavitt. Incredible, excellent video, hearkening back to Giants of Land, Sea & Air - Past & Present (Peters 1986). Just a tweak or two necessary for the included Pteranodon. Extend those metacarpals and elevate that stance!

image:image.image:title: apatemys-insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Apatemys, only complete fossil skeleton of an apatemyid, turns out to be a basal shrew. So this clade is not extinct.

image:image.image:title: scutisorex_lat588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Scutisorex (below) and Crocidura (above) are extant shrews.

image:image.image:title: scutisorex-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The shrew Scutisorex compared to the apatemyid, Labidolemur from the early Eocene. Despite the difference in time, the teeth are still quite comparable.

image:image.image:title: dactylopsila-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Dactylopsila skull and in vivo. This taxon bears a strong resemblance to Apatemys by convergence.

image:image.image:title: Caenolestidae588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on primates and basal glires, including the caenolestids, Caenolestes and Rhyncholestes.

image:image.image:title: caenolestes3view588

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Grallator illustration from Li et al. 2019 with two basal phytodinosaur possible sisters to the track maker, Pampadromaeus and Saturnalia.

image:image.image:title: male_hair_worldwide588

image:image.image:title: Aptornis_skull588

image:image.image:title: rhamphorhynchus-muensteri588

image:image.image:title: Tyrrell-Rhamphorhynchus-fulltorso
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Torso of Rhamphorhynchus from Hone et al. 2015. Above as originally interpreted. Below using DGS. What Hone et al. identify as a mcÂ (metacarpal) is the radius + ulna. Scale bar = 2 cm. One rib is actually aÂ prepubis. An extra sacral rib is identified here. The coracoids are in light blue. The light gray areas maybe an egg. A smaller second possible egg is also in gray. The sternal complex (not just the sternum) appears to be broken into several parts. Fibula parts are identified along with a second ischium.

image:image.image:title: Rhamphorhynchus-pelvis-recon
image:image.image:caption: Figure 11. Pelvic elements of Rhamphorhynchus, Tyrrell specimen, replaced to their in vivo positions in lateral view along with the two possible egg candidates for comparison to the pelvic opening. Seems like a good fit.

image:image.image:title: fig-6-full-rightwing-tip

image:image.image:title: fig-5-fullright-wing

image:image.image:title: fig-6-full-leftwing

image:image.image:title: LRT_test1

image:image.image:title: test2

image:image.image:title: sauropodomorpha
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cladogram from xx 2019, colors added. Marasuchus is not an outgroup to the Dinosauria. In the LRT it nests as a basal theropod.

image:image.image:title: Libonectes-flippers588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Libonectes flippers. 2nd frame shows PILs. Terrestrial tetrapods flex and extend along continuous PILs. The in vivo misalignment of phalanges in Libonectes largely prevents flexion and extension, creating a large stiff flipper at misaligned PILs. Those that are more proximal are continuous, permitting a limited amount of flexion and extension.

image:image.image:title: monodelphis-lat-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Monodelphis skull in three views. Note the supra occipital is narrower than the exoccipitals, like other mammals, not like the data from the figure previously used.

image:image.image:title: metatheria588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT focusing on the Metatheria (=Marsupials). Here the diprotodont dentition evolved twice.

image:image.image:title: procoptodon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Procoptodon is a basal kangaroo, close to Interatherium (Fig. 3).

image:image.image:title: Procoptodon-Interatherium588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skulls of Procoptodon (short-faced kangaroo) alongside Interatherium (ancestral kangaroo) and Dendrolagus (basal kangaroo).

image:image.image:title: Interatherium588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Interatherium is the surprising ancestor of kangaroos, with a special affinity to the short-face kangaroo.

image:image.image:title: A new symmetrodont mammal (Trechnotheria: Zhangheotheriidae) fro
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Anebodon luoi subjected to DGS tracing and phylogenetic analysis nests with Macropus, the extant kangaroo, not with Zhangheotherium. The kangaroo kink is just starting here with a concave/convex maxilla. The canines are present, but tiny. The anterior dentary teeth extend anteriorly, the first step toward the kangaroo's 'tusks'.

image:image.image:title: basal_mammals588

image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Cosesaurus hind limbs. The upper one is exposed on the fossil. The lower one is preserved beneath the medusa. The tarsals are not displaced in the latter.

image:image.image:title: cosesaurus-hand_insitu588

image:image.image:title: cosesaurus-uropatagium588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Cosesaurus uropatagium. This trait is recorded on pterosaurs, Sharovipteryx and Longisquama.

image:image.image:title: Cosesaurus72
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Cosesaurus dorsal frill. This frill evolves into giant plumes on another Cosesaurus descendant, Longisquama.

image:image.image:title: Cosesaurus_crest588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cosesaurus nasal crest (in yellow).

image:image.image:title: cosesaurus_skull_frills
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Cosesaurus skull frills and gular sac.

image:image.image:title: cosesaurus_forelimb588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cosesaurus torso and forelimbs. The hot pink stem-like coracoids are found in pterosaurs. So are the strap-like scapula, distinct from the discs found in Macrocnemus. There is a close association of the clavicles, interclavicle and sternum. In pterosaurs this is known as a sternal complex.

image:image.image:title: cosesaurus-prepubis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The pelvis of Cosesaurus with prepubis in green and 5 sacrals, not 2 as Saller interprets the fossil.

image:image.image:title: Cosesaurus_skull_compared72
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The skull of Cosesaurus traced using DGS methods and lit at various angles. Some of these are negatives of a negative mold, giving a positive view. Saller was not sure about the antorbital fenestra, probably because it is represented by an elevated portion in the mold.

image:image.image:title: Qianxisaurus_pectoral_girdle588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. The Qianxisaurus pectoral girdle is ancestral to the Cartorhynchus pectoral girdle with similarly shaped elements. Compare to figure 1.

image:image.image:title: A new eosauropterygian (Diapsida, Sauropterygia) from the Triass
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Slight changes to the temple region of Qianxisaurus shows the reappearance of the suptratemporal, which had been lost in more primitive taxa only to be reacquired here and further elaborated in Cartorhynchus.

image:image.image:title: Cartorhynchus-recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cartorhynchus reconstruction in lateral and dorsal views with new lateral view skull and pectoral girdle.

image:image.image:title: Cartorhynchus-lenticarpus-insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. New tracing and reconstruction of the basal sauropterygian with flippers, Cartorhynchus. See text for details.

image:image.image:title: plesiosaurs_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Subset of the LRT focusing on plesiosaurs and their ancestors. This study is different than other published work in nesting Hauffiosaurus basal to Pistosaurus and Rhamaleosaurus basal to pliosaurs + plesiosaurs.

image:image.image:title: plesiosaurus_skull_3views588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Plesiosaurus skull in several views alongside the pectoral girdle.

image:image.image:title: Libonectes_atlasense_skull2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The skull of Libonectes. Freehand drawing from Carpenter xxxx. DGS colors added here. Some parts of the original fossil may be restored.

image:image.image:title: jeholosaurus-pes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Jeholosaurus pes in ventral aspect. DGS colors identify parts of pedal digit 5 disarticulated and broken on the sole of the foot and reconstructed at right.

image:image.image:title: origin-of-birds1000
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The origin of birds cladogram. Large clades are colorized.

image:image.image:title: vertebrate_paleontology
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Vertebrate Paleontology by M. Benton.

image:image.image:title: echinosorex-moonrat-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Echinosorex, the extant moonrat, looks like an opossum, but nests with Deinogalerix in the large reptile tree.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Deinogalerix skeleton.

image:image.image:title: Deinogalerix_koenigswaldi-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull of Deinogalerix with bones colored in DGS overlay.

image:image.image:title: A new eosauropterygian (Diapsida, Sauropterygia) from the Triass
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Sauropterygian sisters to Cartorhynchus (green) compared to ichthyosaurian sister candidates. No ichthyosaurs have a short snout and flat belly. Cartorhynchus and sauropterygians swim with their flippers. All ichthyosaurs swim with their tails. Cartorhynchus nests between Pachypleurosaurus and Qianxisaurus in the large reptile tree.

image:image.image:title: Cartorhynchus-lenticarpus-insitu-pectoral
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1b. Cartorhynchus with pectoral bones colorized here. Click to enlarge. This specimen nests with basal pachypleurosaurs. It's not a basal ichthyosaur. It's an ichthyosaur-mimic. Due to the large orbit, short rostrum and lack of phalangeal ossification, this is probably a juvenile and perhaps a very young one. Or not. We'll have to see when more specimens are found.

image:image.image:title: chaohusaurus-AGM CHS-5-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Chaohusaurus nested as a sister to Cartorhynchus in the Motani et al. tree, and they do indeed resemble one another. The posterior half is hypothetical. Adding Cartorhynchus to the ichthyosaurs adds 35 steps.

image:image.image:title: catorhynchus
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Where Cartorhynchus nests in the large reptile tree. Click to enlarge. It is a unique reptile, which makes its nesting all the more of a challenge. Motani et al. did not include mesosaurs.

image:image.image:title: mtoani-tree
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The Motani et al. tree with corrections in black. Nice to see Wumengosaurus at the base of the Ichthyosauria. The mesosaurs are absent, tucked away in 'parareptilia.'

image:image.image:title: chaohusaurus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Chaohusaurus nested as a sister to Catorhynchus in the Motani et al. tree, and they do indeed resemble one another. Adding Catorhynchus to the ichthyosaurs adds 35 steps.

image:image.image:title: teraterpeton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Teraterpeton with new elements added. Toes are largely unknown, but added here based on proximal phalanges.

image:image.image:title: Teraterpeton_cladogram_Pritchard_Sues588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cladogram from Pritchard and Sues 2019 showing the nesting of Teraterpeton with Trilophosaurus. The yellow taxa are lepidosauromorphs and the green taxa are archosauromorphs in the LRT. Taxon exclusion folds them together like a deck of cards.

image:image.image:title: crexcrex_skull
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Skull of Crex most closely resembles that of the new Crex sister, Eofingillirostrum.

image:image.image:title: Eofringillirostrum_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Eofringillirostrum in situ at full scale at 72 dpi and closeups of the skull in situ with DGS tracing and reconstructed. Note the slender vomer (purple).

image:image.image:title: Eofringillirostrum-insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Much enlarged Eofringillirostrum with original tracing and DGS colors. The crest of the sternum, originally overlooked, is just barely ossified here.

image:image.image:title: crex_invivo
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. The extant corn crake (Crex) is a living relative of the giant elephant bird.

image:image.image:title: turtle_scapula-lyson2013-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. On the left, from Lyson et al. 2013 with graphics added. On the right taxa basal to turtles according to the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Albertonectes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Click to enlarge. Albertonectes reconstructed for the first time. This 11 m Â (37') elasmosaur is the longest thus far recorded. With such a large neck, one wonders whether this reptile developed thrust with this sea snake-like neck, but this is countered by the flat articulations and short processes that restrict such movement. The neck was relatively stiff, which is why it broke into sections upon reaching the sea floor.

image:image.image:title: CM-73372-in-situ_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. CM73372 in situ and reconstructed using DGS methodology. At first glance it seems to be a biped with short fingers, like Postosuchus. In situ image from Weinbaum 2013.

image:image.image:title: Nyctosaurus-bonneri-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure x. With such a short humerus it appears unlikely that this Nyctosaurus could achieve a forelimb launch of sufficient height and length to deploy those long wing fingers before crashing.

image:image.image:title: lander
image:image.image:caption: Figure x. Click to animate. Animation of a landing pterosaur matched to tracks.

image:image.image:title: kangaroo skeleton
image:image.image:caption: Figure x. Click to enlarge. Here a kangaroo skeleton is compared to that of a quadrupedally leaping pterosaur. The red arrows on the kangaroo indicate the major muscle pulls employed during each leap. Even with all those muscles, tensioned tendons and bone levers, kangaroo leaps only lift the toes to the height of the ankles. The pterosaur is less well-equipped with only a single major lever, the elbow as it straightens a very short distance, bound by the propatagium in front _preventing_ overextension of the elbow.

image:image.image:title: albatrossvideo
image:image.image:caption: Albatross video showing take-off in a no headwind situation. Running and flapping provides sufficient airspeed to provide lift.

image:image.image:title: pteranodon-wing-launching3
image:image.image:caption: Click to play. Successful heretical bird-style Pteranodon wing launch in which the hind limbs produce far less initial thrust because the first downstroke of the already upraised wing provides the necessary thrust for takeoff in the manner of birds. This assumes a standing start and not a running start in the manner of lizards. Note three wing beats take place in the same space and time that only one wing beat takes place in the Habib/Molnar model.

image:image.image:title: Anhanguera-manus588
image:image.image:caption: Errors in the Habib/Molnar reconstruction of the pterosaur manus

image:image.image:title: jayne-lizard-video
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Click to play video. Just how fast can quadrupedal/bipedal lizards run? This video documents 11 meters/second in a Callisaurus at the Bruce Jayne lab.

image:image.image:title: pteranodon-wing-launching3
image:image.image:caption: Successful heretical bird-style Pteranodon wing launch in which the hind limbs produce far less initial thrust because the first downstroke of the already upraised wings provides the necessary thrust for takeoff in the manner of birds. This assumes a standing start and not a running start in the manner of lizards. Note three wing beats take place in the same space that only wing wing beat takes place in the widely accepted wing launch model of Habib (2008).

image:image.image:title: benton-nesbitt-archosauria
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Click to enlarge. Shown here are trees from Gauthier 1986, Sereno 1991, Benton 1999, and Nesbitt 2011, all from Wikipedia's article on archosaurs.
