image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. The BES SC 111 specimen of Macrocnemus with dorsal frills like Litorosuchus.

image:image.image:title: litorosuchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Litorosuchus somnii was wrongly considered a sister to Vancleavea and wrongly considered an archosauriform. In the LRT it nests with Macrocnemus, a tritosaur lepidosaur that also has members with an antorbital fenestra. Click to see an enlarged rollover image.

image:image.image:title: MacroBESSC111-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Macrocnemus specimen BES SC 111 reconstructed with uropatagia, based on Renesto and Avanzini 2002.

image:image.image:title: llistrofus-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Llistrofus is very much like Tuditanus, but with such reduced squamosals that a lateral temporal fenestra appears.

image:image.image:title: huttenlocker588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cladogram of basal tetrapods from Huttenlocker et al. 2009 with colors added.

image:image.image:title: maiabalaena-cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Cladogram from Peredo et al. 2018. Colors added to show members of the odontocete/ archaoecete clade (red tint) and the mysticete clade (cyan tint) in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Cetotheres_to_scale588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. A selection of cetotheres, including Maiabalaena, to scale.

image:image.image:title: maiabalaena-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Maiabalaena is a close relative of Yamatocetus in the LRT, not a transitional taxon to archaeocete whales.

image:image.image:title: protopterosaurus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. "Protopterosaurus" the hopeful hypothetical ancestor of pterosaurs created by Wild (1984) and supported by Wellnhofer (1991).

image:image.image:title: alt_amphibian_cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. 4-frame GIF animation showing results for taxon exclusion. If you don't want to read the taxa, just watch the colored clades as they bounce around.

image:image.image:title: laosuchus_lateral588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Laosuchus in dorsal and lateral views. Colors added with some difficulty here as all the bones are fused and their surfaces are ornamented.

image:image.image:title: Redescription and phylogenetic relationships of Solenodonsaurus
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Solenodonsaurus skull in situ and reconstructed. That brown bone on top of the frontal/parietal suture is a displaced lacrimal that nicely fills the gap in the reconstruction.

image:image.image:title: laosuchus_chroniosuchia_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Cladogram from xx 2018 with Laosuchus nesting with chroniosuchians in the absence of Solenodonsaurus.

image:image.image:title: cochleosaurus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Cochleosaurus in situ and restored by Rieppel 1980 and Godfrey and Holmes 1995. Here the septomaxilla is reidentified as the lacrimal and the lacrimal is the palatine exposed on the surface as in all sister taxa of its clade.

image:image.image:title: carnotaurus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Carnotaurus skull. Note the traditional frontals are much reduced here. The horns are comprised of the lacrimals + prefrontals.

image:image.image:title: pholidocercus-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Pholidocercus skull with DGS colors added. Distinct from most members of the Glires, the canine becomes more robust in the hedgehog clade. Note the posterior jaw joint, the opposite of mouse-like rodents.

image:image.image:title: pholidocercus-insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Only one of the several Messel Pit Pholidocercus specimens. This one has a truncated tail and a halo of soft tissue (pre-spines).

image:image.image:title: stegops_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Stegops skull retraced and reconstructed in dorsal and lateral views, plus the version provided by Moodie 1916. Here the squamosal 'spikes' are reconstructed as a deeply excavated squamosal like the one in Tersomius.

image:image.image:title: dissorophus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Dissorophus nests with Stegops among basal lepospondyls in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: eupleres_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Eupleres is a Madagascar mongoose with a long, tree-shrew-like skull with a longer premaxilla.

image:image.image:title: herpestes_skull2_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Egyptian mongoose, Herpestes, develops a postorbital bar arising from the layered postfrontal and postorbital reappearing in this clade.

image:image.image:title: nyctosaurus_unsm93000_fingers588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Closeup of the UNSM 93000 specimen of Nyctosaurus focusing on three vestige free fingers.

image:image.image:title: eretmorhipis_cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on Mesosauria, Thalattosauriformes and Ichthyopterygia including two specimens referred to Eretmorhipis nesting here apart from one another.

image:image.image:title: eretmorhipis_compared_to_headless588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The holotype specimen of Eretmorhipis carrolldongi WGSC V26020 compared to the figure drawn form Cheng et al. 2019.

image:image.image:title: eretmorhipis_cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on Mesosauria, Thalattosauriformes and Ichthyopterygia including Eretmorhipis and Hupehsuchia.

image:image.image:title: eretmorhipis-recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Reconstruction of Eretmorhipis skull from figure 1, along with in situ specimen and reconstruction from Cheng et al. 2019. Pectoral and pelvic girdles magnified and colored using DGS methods. The skull appears to provide binocular vision due to the narrow rostrum and wide cranium.

image:image.image:title: ornithorhynchus_skull_3views588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Ornithorhynchus skull with colors added using DGS methods. Note the large opening in the dorsal view of the rostrum, as in Eretmorhipis.

image:image.image:title: eretmorhipis-carrolldongi.insitu.588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Eremorhipis in situ and line drawing from Cheng et al. 2019. Colored here using DGS methods. Some bones are reidentified here. See figure 2 for matching colors.

image:image.image:title: archosauria
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Archosauria according to the large study

image:image.image:title: Sauropod-pes-evolution588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Sauropod pedal evolution. Here metatarsal 1 was shorter and more gracile in predecessor taxa, but in basal sauropods metatarsal 1 became more robust. In sauropods all the metatarsals became reduced and lateral phalanges were lost.

image:image.image:title: Sauropod-pes-evolution588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Sauropod pedal evolution. Here metatarsal 1 was shorter and more gracile in predecessor taxa, but in basal sauropods metatarsal 1 became more robust. In sauropods all the metatarsals became reduced and lateral phalanges were lost.

image:image.image:title: basalarchosaurs300
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Basal archosaurs.

image:image.image:title: tyrannosaur-ancestors2
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Tyrannosaur ancestors to scale according to the large reptile tree. Drag to desktop to enlarge.

image:image.image:title: tyrannosaur-ancestors1
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Tyrannosaur ancestors according to Brusatte, artwork by Todd Marshall. Those on the left are actually closer to allosaurs and spinosaurs. Drag to desktop to enlarge.

image:image.image:title: tyrannosaur_ancestors
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the large retile tree focusing on theropods. Note the green taxa. While technically basal to tyrannosaurs, this clade is actually closer to allosaurs and spinosaurs. And the Brusatte text does not consider Zhenyuanlong, Tianyuraptor, Fukuiraptor and Ornitholestes.

image:image.image:title: Rise_of_the-tyrannosaurs-cover
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Rise of the Tyrannosaurs by Stephen Brusatte, Scientific American

image:image.image:title: cabarzia-vaughnictis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Cabarzia compared to Vaughnictis and Apsisaurus to scale. Finger 1 and other phalanges were identified in published photos of this specimen (Fig. 1) using DGS tracing and reconstruction methods.

image:image.image:title: early_permian_earth588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Early Permian Earth, prior to the separation of Europe from North America.

image:image.image:title: archosauromorpha588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal Archosauromorpha including Vaughnictis and Cabarzia nesting at the base of the Protodiapsid-Synapsid split. Note all the large varanopids nest together here in the Synapsida, separate from small varanopids in the Protodiapsida.

image:image.image:title: cabarzia_pelvis2
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 4. Pelvis of Cabarzia colored with DGS. Note the offset femoral head perforating the pelvis, the anterior process of the illiim and the four sacral vertebrae, all pointing to bipedal locomotion. Some of this was overlooked by Spindler et al.

image:image.image:title: cabarzia_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Cabarzia in situ and tracing distorted to fit the photo from Spindler, et al. 2019. Inserts show manus and pes with DGS colors and reconstructions. Scale bar = 5 cm.

image:image.image:title: cabarzia-vaughnictis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Cabarzia compared to Vaughnictis and Protorothyris to scale.

image:image.image:title: spindler-2016-cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 3. Spindler et al. 2016 cladogram suffering from massive taxon exclusion.

image:image.image:title: mesenosaurus-compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Two specimens attributed to Mesenosaurus compared to scale with Cabarzia. Scale bar = 5cm.

image:image.image:title: babyostrich_with_nostril
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Baby ostrich naris still does not match patch from Witmer 2012 video.

image:image.image:title: witmer-dino-nares-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Witmer 2001 showing brachiosaur sauropod skull, colors added. Witmer suggests the nostril might have been located at point 'B' in the maxillary basin (blue) rather than in the external naris (red).

image:image.image:title: ostrich_head_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Ostrich skull compared to ostrich head with nostril appearing within the external naris.

image:image.image:title: sauropod-nostrils588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Four sauropods with external nares identified in pink, internal nares in blue.

image:image.image:title: dinohyus_hollandi_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull of Dinohyus + Daedon with bones colored using DGS. Note the reappearance of the postorbital ring composed of postfrontal and postorbital. The jugal extends to the jaw joint, something that usually only happens in marsupials. The jaw joint is at the back of the skull, convergent with some multituberculates, crowding out the ear bones. Not much of ascent on that coronoid process of the dentary. And is that a splenial poking out as a mandible horn?

image:image.image:title: basal_lepidosauriformes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Basal lepidosauriformes to scale from Tridentinosaurus (Earliest Permian) to Huehuecuetzpalli (Early Cretaceous). Subtle differences lump and split these taxa into their various clades.

image:image.image:title: merycopotamus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Merycopotamus skull and mandible with colors identifying the reappearances of the prefrontal and postfrontal.

image:image.image:title: agriochoerus_antiquus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Agriochoerus is a late-surviving oreodont with a diastema and a sister to Merycoidodon.

image:image.image:title: oreodont_mesonychid_mysticete_clade588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The oreodont-mesonychid-hippo-desmoystlian-mysticete clade subset of the LRT

image:image.image:title: hippopotamus_paleoparadoxia_2scale
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Merycopotamus, Hippopotamus, and Paleoparadoxia compared to scale.

image:image.image:title: merycoidodon_cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. the Merycoidodon cladogram includes hippos, whales and a number of extinct taxa.

image:image.image:title: merycoidodon_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Merycoidodon skull. Colors added.

image:image.image:title: merycoidodon_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Merycoidodon reconstruction traced by an unknown artist from an AMNH mount photo.

image:image.image:title: lewisuchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Lewisuchus, a tiny predecessor to crocs and dinos (including birds).

image:image.image:title: dinos2
image:image.image:caption: Dinosaurs: A Concise Natural History by Fastovsky and Weishampel 2012

image:image.image:title: Archosaurs-Peters
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Click to enlarge. The family tree of Archosaurs and their ancestors according to the large reptile tree by Peters. Note the absence here of phytosauria, proterochampsia (including lagerpetidae) and pterosauromorpha all of which nest far afield in the large reptile tree. A few taxa are added here. As in Nesbitt's tree, the major radiation occurred during the early Triassic and rather quickly. Here most dinosaur groups had a long ghost lineage into the Early Triassic, except, possibly, the Ornithischia evolving from Daemonosaurus

image:image.image:title: Archosaurs-Peters
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Click to enlarge. The family tree of Archosaurs and their ancestors according to the large reptile tree by Peters. Note the absence here of phytosauria, proterochampsia (including lagerpetidae) and pterosauromorpha all of which nest far afield in the large reptile tree. A few taxa are added here. As in Nesbitt's tree, the major radiation occurred during the early Triassic and rather quickly. Here most dinosaur groups had a long ghost lineage into the Early Triassic, except, possibly, the Ornithischia evolving from Daemonosaurus

image:image.image:title: Archosaurs-Nesbitt
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The family tree of Archosaurs and their ancestors by Sterling Nesbitt.

image:image.image:title: dinosaur-origins1
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The origin of dinosaurs as portrayed by the phylogenetic series of closest known sister taxa to the actual unknown undiscovered true lineage of dinosaurs. A. Youngina, B. Proterosuchus, C. Garjainia, D. Euparkeria, Vjushkovia, 1. Ticinosuchus, 2. Yarasuchus, 3. Decuriasuchus, 4. Turfanosuchus, 5. Gracilisuchus, 6. PVL 4597, 7. Trialestes, 8. Herrerasaurus, 9. Marasuchus, 10. Daemonosaurus.

image:image.image:title: dino-tree
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Family tree of the Archosauria and basal Dinosauria. Bootstrap scores are shown.

image:image.image:title: dino-tree
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Family tree of the Archosauria and basal Dinosauria. Bootstrap scores are shown.

image:image.image:title: origin-of-dinosaurs-skulls
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Origin of dinosaurs documented by skulls shown at constant length in evolutionary order. Shown here are Decuriasuchus, Turfanosuchus, Lewisuchus, Pseudhesperosuchus, Trialestes, Herrerasaurus, Eoraptor and Tawa, not to scale.

image:image.image:title: origin_of-dinosaurs
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The origin of dinosaurs using constant length specimens. Here Decuriasuchus, Turfanosuchus, Gracilisuchus, Lewisuchus, Pseudhesperosuchus, Trialestes and Herrerasaurus not to scale.

image:image.image:title: origin_of-dinosaurs-to-scale
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The origin of dinosaurs to scale. Gray arrows show the direction of evolution. This image includes Decuriasuchus, Turfanosuchus, Gracilisuchus, Lewisuchus, Pseudhesperosuchus, Trialestes, Herrerasaurus, Tawa and Eoraptor.

image:image.image:title: origin_of_dinosaurs_video
image:image.image:caption: Click to view Origin of Dinosaurs and Birds video now on YouTube.

image:image.image:title: proto-dinosaurs
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Proto-dinosaurs including Zupaysaurus and Megapnosaurus.

image:image.image:title: coelophysis-skull-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Coelophysis skull for comparison.

image:image.image:title: zupaysaurus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Zupaysaurus nests with Megapsnosaurus as a proto-dinosaur.

image:image.image:title: Megapnosaurus_palates
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The palates of Coelophyis and Megapnosaurus (illustrated by Cope 1989) together with the palates of Lewisuchus and Pseudhesperosuchus in phylogenetic order based on the large reptile tree. Note the gradual evolution of the elements here and the certainty that Megapnosaurus is not congeneric with Coelophysis. The palates of Lewisuchus and Pseudhesperosuchus are evidently only partially preserved. These line drawings are the only data currently available here.Â

image:image.image:title: Archosauria-dinosauria-cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Click to enlarge. Subset of the large reptile tree focusing on the Archosauria (crocs + dinos). Sharp-eyed observers will find minor changes here.

image:image.image:title: uintatherium-skull-lat588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Uintatherium skull with bones colored and labeled. Several of these bones have not been seen on mammal skulls, but once appeared on basal synapsid skulls.

image:image.image:title: uintathere-family-399
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Uintathere evolution from Wheeler 1961. Colors and eyeballs added.

image:image.image:title: bathyopsis-uintatherium588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Bathyopsis, xx and Uintatherium to the same fang-occiput length showing the reappearance of several bones that don't appear in most mammals. See text for details.

image:image.image:title: origin_of-dinosaurs-to-scale
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The origin of dinosaurs to scale. Gray arrows show the direction of evolution. This image includes Decuriasuchus, Turfanosuchus, Gracilisuchus, Lewisuchus, Pseudhesperosuchus, Trialestes, Herrerasaurus, Tawa and Eoraptor.

image:image.image:title: origin_of-dinosaurs-to-scale
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The origin of dinosaurs to scale. Gray arrows show the direction of evolution. This image includes Decuriasuchus, Turfanosuchus, Gracilisuchus, Lewisuchus, Pseudhesperosuchus, Trialestes, Herrerasaurus, Tawa and Eoraptor.

image:image.image:title: origin-of-proto-dinosaurs
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Origin of the dinosaurs and protodinosaurs. Here Gracilisuchus, at the base of the Crocodylomorpha and Archosauria, is basal to the PVL 4597 specimen attributed to Gracilisuchus, Lewisuchus and Pseudhesperosuchus, taxa leading to Herrerasaurus at the base of the Dinosauria.

image:image.image:title: rhynchocyon-petersi-skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Skeleton of the elephant shrew, Rhynchocyon. Note the digitigrade manus and pes, like those of basal artiodactyls.

image:image.image:title: siamotherium-pondaungensis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Siamotherium to scale with Anagale. Both nest basal to the tenrec-odontocete clade.

image:image.image:title: coeruleodraco_manus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Manus of Coeruleodraco as originally identified and repaired and reconstructed in color.

image:image.image:title: coeruleodraco_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Coeruleodraco skull as originally interpreted (below) and interpreted here (colors). This is a traditional error. Also note the remnants of an antorbital fenestra in this phylogenetically miniaturized taxon. The maxilla continues posterior to the orbit as in other choristoderes.

image:image.image:title: champsosaurus.skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Champsosaurus skull with premaxilla in yellow.

image:image.image:title: carnivora-genomic-flynn2005
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Carnivora according to Flynn et al. 2005 based on genomic testing.

image:image.image:title: mustela_miacis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Mustela and Miacis (the mink/weasel) compared to scale.

image:image.image:title: bird_origins
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Bird origins. Apparently the four-winged micro raptors were no in the direct line of living birds.

image:image.image:title: theropod-cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Latest cladogram of the Theropoda, including the Compsognathus-Tyrannosaurus clade.

image:image.image:title: sinornithosaurus_pelvis200
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Sinornithosaurus (holotype) pelvis. Note the pubis is oriented ventrally, then curves posteriorly.

image:image.image:title: tyrannosaur_clade588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Taxa in the Compsognathus/Tyrannosaurus clade, a subset of the large reptile tree to scale. Also included are Microraptor, Sinornithosaurus, Dilong and Zhenyuanlong.

image:image.image:title: compsognathus-pelecanimimus
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Pelecanimimus to scale with Struthiomimus and Compsognathus.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. DGS tracings from 1994 paper focusing on skull and manus of Pelecanimimus.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Rough tracing and reconstruction of Pelecanimimus based on low rez photos from 1994 paper.

image:image.image:title: zygodactyl_birds
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Several birds with zygodactyl feet (light red) and one member of the clade Zygodactylidae (red).

image:image.image:title: galago-demidoff-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Galago skull in three views.

image:image.image:title: galago_senegalensis_skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Galago skeleton. Note the elongate tarsals and large orbits, both convergent with Tarsius.

image:image.image:title: gunnell-et-al-(2018)-plesiopithecus-propotto588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. How Gunnell et al. 'Pulled a Larry Martin'. They cherry-picked taxa. They focused on just a few traits in the mandible. They hope that four tiny incisors might evolve into two giant incisors.

image:image.image:title: perodicticus_potto_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Perodicticus potto, the extant potto, has a typical lemur dentition, lacking giant incisors.

image:image.image:title: lemur_catta_skeleton_invivo588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Lemur catta in vivo and skeleton.

image:image.image:title: propotto-left-and-plesiopithecus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Propotto and Plesiopithecus nest with Daubentonia in Gunnell et al. 2018, which does not test many rodents, despite the rodent-like teeth shown here.

image:image.image:title: caluromys_hand_foot
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Caluromys hand and foot from Argot 2002 compared to Didelphis and repaired here to match.

image:image.image:title: pararchosauriformes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Pararchosauriformes. Only the larger taxa are visible here.

image:image.image:title: protertre3400
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Left: A segment of the large reptile tree showing what happens when more taxa are included. The Pararchosauriformes form a branch separate from the Euarchosauriformes and develop an antorbital fenestra and foss by convergence. Right: Reducing the branch on the left to include only those taxa chosen by Dilkes and Arcucci (2012) with the addition of the thalattosaur, Vancleavea, mistakenly chosen for inclusion by Dilkes and Arcucci (2012).

image:image.image:title: chanaresuchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Chanaresuchus a quadrupedal ancestor to Tropidosuchus and Lagerpeton and the third Tropidosuchus-like taxon.

image:image.image:title: Tropidosuchus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The holotype of Tropidosuchus retains the narrower digit 4 of Chanaresuchus.

image:image.image:title: tropidolago2recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. A skeleton attributed to Tropidosuchus, but shares traits with Lagerpeton.

image:image.image:title: PII: S1367-9120(02)00110-4
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Pamelaria compared to the skull of Azendohsaurus. The description of the postcrania of Azendohsaurus by Nesbitt et al. matches that of Pamelaria.

image:image.image:title: teraterpeton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Teraterpeton, a former enigma that nests here between Chanaresuchus and Tropidosuchus.

image:image.image:title: helveticosaurus-vancleavea588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Vancleavea with its sister, Helveticosaurus.

image:image.image:title: vancleavea-erythrosuchus
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Vancleavea surrounded by purported sister taxa as figured by Nesbitt and Wikipedia. None of these taxa share more traits with Vancleavea than does Helveticosaurus, a taxon ignored since it was proposed here.

image:image.image:title: Trilophosaurus-Azendosaurus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Azendohsaurus compared to sister taxa and putative sister taxa including Trllophosaurus, Pamelaria, Teraterpeton, Sapheosaurus and Leptosaurus. Diandongosaurus is ghosted as it is a tested sister to Teraterpeton. Azendohsaurus nests with Trilophosaurus in both studies. Even so it is quite distinct.

image:image.image:title: Sapheosaurus_laticeps_skull
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Sapheosaurus GIF animation. This smaller ancestral sister to Azendohsaurus was overlooked and excluded by the Nesbitt et al. study.

image:image.image:title: Eohyosaurus-skull300
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Eohyosaurus nests as a sister to the Trilophosaurus-Azendohsaurus clade.

image:image.image:title: azendohsaurus-skull-corrected250
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Azendohsaurus skull reconstructed with two premaxillary teeth, not four.

image:image.image:title: Nesbitt-subset-azendohsaurus-tree
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. A subset of the large reptile tree matched to the Nesbitt et al. 2015 taxon list. Here the tree mixes taxa from the two major branches demonstrating the convergence of the derived taxa and the importance of including a large gamut (610) of tested and verified taxa rather than fewer than 30 favorites or traditional guesses.

image:image.image:title: trilophosaurus-skulls588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Trilophosaurus skulls. Note the deep jugal on two and the shallow jugal on the third. Also note the postjugal bone, a novel ossification.

image:image.image:title: azendohsaurus-cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Rhynchocephalian subset of the large reptile tree with Azendohsaurus highlighted.

image:image.image:title: untitled
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Nesbitt et al. 2015 cladogram nesting Azendohsaurus between Trilophosaurus + Teraterpeton and Pamelaria. This is not supported by the large reptile tree. Here green taxa are lepidosauromorphs. Black taxa are archosauromorphs.

image:image.image:title: Azhdenosaurus
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Reconstruction of Azhendohsaurus from Nesbitt et al. 2015. Manus on left. Pes on right.

image:image.image:title: basal_lepidosauriformes_cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal lepidosauriformes and Jesairosaurus at the base of the Jesairosauria.

image:image.image:title: Teraterpeton-skull-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Teraterpeton skull. Note the confluent naris/antorbital fenestra.

image:image.image:title: teraterpeton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Diandongosuchus (above) compared to Teraterpeton (below). Note the similar scapula shapes and the way the posterior dorsal ribs terminate in a line. Both lack the flaring cheeks of parasuchians and Youngina. Teraterpeton, with so few teeth, could well have been a plant eater or anything but a carnivore. Hopefully we'll find more of this genus someday.

image:image.image:title: teraterpeton_trilophosaurus_compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skulls of Teraterpeton and Trilophosaurus compared.

image:image.image:title: paleorhinus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Paleorhinus also has a tall ilium with an anterior process like that of rhynchosaurs, AND it is closely related to Teraterpeton in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: 580px-catopsbaatar_jaw_muscles
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Jaw muscles of the Late Cretaceous multituberculate, Catopsbaatar.

image:image.image:title: arboroharamiya_middle_ear588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Multituberculate Arboroharamiya skull and middle ear. Note the reversal to the quadrate-articular (=incus-malleus), along with the reduction of the ectotympanic preserved in this specimen.

image:image.image:title: paulchoffatia-megaconus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. LRT taxa in the lineage of multituberculates arising from Carpolestes and Paulchoffatia.

image:image.image:title: glires_primates588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2b. Subset of the LRT focusing on Primates + Glires.

image:image.image:title: megaconus-skull-insitu
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Megaconus mammaliaformis in situ and reconstructed. Compare to the similar, but smaller Vilevolodon.

image:image.image:title: rugosodon_skull_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 9. The skull of Rugosodon. There are no tiny post dentary bones present here according to the original authors or my own tracings.

image:image.image:title: kryptobaatar_skull3views588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. The skull of the multituberculate Kryptobataar, which now nests as a rodent in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: eomaia_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Eomaia skull traced and reconstructed. Eomaia nests between marsupials and placentals. Note the unspecialized skull and dentition. Megaconus has a very specialized dentition.

image:image.image:title: Megaconus-skull-insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Megaconus soul with original outline tracing. Note they missed lots of detail, but marked the tiny angular (green triangle). In DGS tracing I don't see what Zhou et al. saw.

image:image.image:title: mammals588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Mammals include rodents. Haramiyadens and multituberculates nest with rodents.

image:image.image:title: Rattus588
image:image.image:caption: Brown Rat (Rattus norvegicus) skull showing how lower incisors are used to scrape away and sharpen upper incisors

image:image.image:title: Haramiyavia
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Haramiyava dentary showing what a more typical stem mammal dentary and teeth look like. Earlier studies linked this clade to multituberculates, but this dentary was cause to reject that association.

image:image.image:title: megaconus_mandible588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Megaconus mandible showing cynodont-like posterior mandible bones, not tiny mammal-like ear bones.

image:image.image:title: Ignacius-daubentonia588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ignacius and Plesiadapis nest basal to Daubentonia in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: rodents
image:image.image:caption: The Wu et al 2012 study on rodents and their post-Cretaceous appearance.

image:image.image:title: plesiadapis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Plesiadapis, formerly considered a basal primate, is here considered a basal arboreal lagomorph (rabbit ancestor).

image:image.image:title: ptilocercus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Ptilocercus, pen-tailed tree shrew, a living relative to the ancestor of bats and colugos.

image:image.image:title: tupaia588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Tupaia, the large tree shrew, a living taxon close to the base of rabbits and rodents with origins in the Paleocene, just following the Cretaceous. Click to learn more.

image:image.image:title: glires72-18multis
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Click to enlarge. See text for explanation.

image:image.image:title: Vilevolodon-middle-ear588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. There is no doubt that Vilevolodon has pre-mammal type post-dentary bones. There is also no doubt that the dentary formed the main jaw joint with the squamosal. How does one reconcile both sets of traits? In the LRT Vilevolodon nests with rodents. This appears to be a mammal with an atavism, a reversal. These elements simply stopped developing as in other mammals.

image:image.image:title: Vilevolodon-skull
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Vilevolodont skull in situ, without color, DGS color tracing, that tracing reconstructed and a CT scan form Luo et al. 2017.

image:image.image:title: Kryptobaatar-dashzevegi-mandible
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. Multituberculate Kryobaatar mandible in lateral and medial views. Here post-dentary bones are absent. The malleus (quadrate) and ectotympanic are on the skull.

image:image.image:title: vilevolodon_insitu
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Vilevolodon in situ, plate, counterplate, original drawing, DGS color, and restored manus and pes. Note the gliding membrane (patagium) and fur.

image:image.image:title: vilevolodon_CT588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Vilevolodon in CT scan from Luo et al. There is no jaw glenoid, Lacking a jaw joint the mandible was held in place by large, interweaving jaw muscles that slightly rotate the mortar and pestle molars within one another during grinding of the food.

image:image.image:title: daubentonia-skeleton_highlights588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Highlights of the aye-aye (Daubentonia) skeleton focusing on the small bones medial to the humerus (procoracoid + coracoid) and the lateral rotation of the ankle and pes where the astragalus still sits on top of the calcaneum, as the dorsal surface of the pes is now lateral.

image:image.image:title: BMNH_3258_pectoral_girdle
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. The pectoral girdle of BMNH 3258, fossil lacking a skull and any post lumbar data. Here a tentative reconstruction is presented that locates the procoracoid and coracoid anterior to the humerus with concave coracoid curves matching convex humerus curves.Â

image:image.image:title: vilevolodon-pes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Original and DGS tracing of the Vilevolodon left pes, here flipped for consistency of presentation. Note the astragalus sits atop the calcaneum, as in other therian mammals and rodents.

image:image.image:title: Vilevolodon-Yanaconodon_jaws_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Basal mammals and Vilevolodon as figured by Meng et al. Note in the other taxa the two jaw joints are nearly coincident. Not so in Vilevolodon.

image:image.image:title: paramys588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Paramys is an extinct rodent with a sliding jaw joint and flattened premolars and molars. Compare to Vilevolodon.

image:image.image:title: vilevolodon_dentary588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Two views of the Vilevolodon skull showing the dentaries from two views, plus atavistic posterior jaw elements here dislocated.

image:image.image:title: Lemur_catta588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Lemur catta skull in 3 views.

image:image.image:title: Aye-aye_squirrel588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Morris, Cobb and Cox 2018, ÂµCT images of Daubentonia and Sciurus.

image:image.image:title: vincelestes-drawing588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Vincelestes drawing compared to Digimorph.org image. Colors applied here. The LRT indicates this is a sister taxon to the highly derived marsupial sabertooth, Thylacosmilus.

image:image.image:title: Braincase_Structure_Mammals588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Braincase bones of pre-mammals and mammals from Hopson and Rougier 1993, with some (Thylacosmilus, Tupaia and Kryptobaatar) added here. Colors added.

image:image.image:title: daubentonia_skull_alone
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Daubentonia skull shares a long list of traits with multituberculate skulls.

image:image.image:title: megazostrodon_molars588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Megazostrodon molars display a tribosphenic cusp arrangement. Therefore all mammals are derived from this cusp pattern.

image:image.image:title: Mammal_tooth_evolution588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Mammal tooth evolution alongside odontocete tooth evolution, reversing the earlier addition of cusps.

image:image.image:title: Discodactylus_paper_model588-3
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Another view of the paper reconstruction of the skull and mandibles of Discodactylus.

image:image.image:title: Discodactylus_paper_model588-1
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Paper reconstruction of the Discodactylus skull and mandibles.

image:image.image:title: basal_placental_skulls
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. A selection of placental skulls in phylogenetic order and divided into Cretaceous and Paleocene taxa.

image:image.image:title: basal_placentals588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. Skeletons of taxa that nest at the bases of several major placental clades, divided between Cretaceous and Paleocene taxa.

image:image.image:title: ectoganus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Ectoganus nests with Stylinodon and Psittacotherium within the Carnivora, derived from Gulo, the wolverine.

image:image.image:title: Australohyaena588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Australohyaena, a big sister to the cat-like marsupial, Oxyaena, in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: rugosodon_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Rugosodon eurasiaticus (Yuan et al. 2013, Late Jurassic, the size of a chimpmunk) is the oldest multituberculate and it is represented by a complete skeleton. Teeth and ankle evidence indicate it was an omnivore and arboreal.

image:image.image:title: tel-aviv-sunrise-3000bc
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. About 5000 years ago (3000BC) the three stars of Orion's belt did indeed align with the rising sun, preceded by Sirius the other brightest star near the Winter solstice.

image:image.image:title: tel-aviv-sunrise-zero
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Tel Aviv sunrise, year zero with red arrows still showing a lack of alignment between the rising sun and Orion's belt stars.

image:image.image:title: telaviv-sunrise-2018
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. In 2018 the stars in the belt of Orion do not align with the rising sun of December 24.

image:image.image:title: conoryctella-pattersoni588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Conoryctella pattersoni nests with the Eutherian herbivore Onychonycteris in the LRT, not with the marsupial Conoryctes.

image:image.image:title: conoryctes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Conoryctes fossil and drawing from Schoch 1986.

image:image.image:title: Borhyaena-tuberata588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 2b. Borhyaena skull cracked and angled to match the glenoid to the jaw joint, distinct from the original illustration (above).

image:image.image:title: borhyaena-tuberata2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Borhyaena compared to the smaller Deltatheridium.

image:image.image:title: marsupial_tree588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on marsupials and Deltatheridium nesting with Borhyaena.

image:image.image:title: deltatheridium_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Deltatheridium skulls, PSS-MAE 132, 133 and AMNH 21706. The back of the skull in the 133 specimen is imagined twice. The elevated posterior rim matches sister taxa like Borhyaena.

image:image.image:title: deltatheridium_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The nesting of Deltatheridium according to Rougier et al. 1998. The LRT does not support this cladogram.

image:image.image:title: huerfanodon_skull_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Heurfanodon skull. This late survivor of a Jurassic radiation is from the Eocene. It is transitional between didelphids and the Vincelestes-Thylacosmilus clade.

image:image.image:title: schowalteria588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Showalteria. Not much there. Adding more rounds out the skull, a likely marsupial relative of Vincelestes.

image:image.image:title: rook-mammalia
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The Rook and Hunter cladogram that nested traditional Taeniodonts within their Eutheria. Colors and tones added here for clarity and comparison. The LRT does not confirm most of these relationships.

image:image.image:title: mammalia-rookhunter2013
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The Rook and Hunter cladogram that nested traditional Taeniodonts within the Mammalia. Colors and tones added here for clarity and comparison.

image:image.image:title: traditional_taeniodonta_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT labeling several traditional taeniodonts in red, indicating the traditional clade Taeniodonta is polyphyletic and should therefore be abandoned.

image:image.image:title: traditional_taeniodonta588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Traditional Taeniodonta in a cladogram. With more taxa this clade splits up according to the colors shown here.

image:image.image:title: metatheria588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on the several clades that currently make up the Metatheria.

image:image.image:title: cimolestes.recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Cimolestes is represented by a toothy mandible. Here it nests with the extant Dasyurus if the back of the skull is shorter. Apparently the coronoid process is oddly narrow.

image:image.image:title: Kerberos588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Kerberos skull in 3 views and colored using DGS methods.

image:image.image:title: Machaeroides_eothen588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Two Machaeroides skulls in the three views.

image:image.image:title: Kerberos_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on the Mustela clade within the Carnivora with the addition of Kerberos and Machaeroides.

image:image.image:title: callistoe.skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Callistoe skull. This taxon nests at the base of the Thylacosmilus clade.

image:image.image:title: sabertooth_marsupials588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Subset of the LRT focusing on the Metatheria. Here sabertooth Patagosmilus nests far apart from sabertooth Thylacosmilus, which nests apart from the clade of borhyaenid marsupials.

image:image.image:title: vincelestes_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Vincelestes soul showing the separation of the nasals and frontals by the conjoined maxillae housing giant canine roots, as in sister Thylacosmilus.

image:image.image:title: hadrocodium_color_bones
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Tiny Hadrocodium (Early Jurassic) nests as a sister to Patagosmilus (middle Miocene) in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Thylacosmilus_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Thylacosmilus skull. Note the deep maxillae in dorsal contact containing giant canine roots. These are not present in Patagosmilus.

image:image.image:title: patagosmilus
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Patagosmilus to scale alongside Hadrocodium. These sabetooth taxa are not directly related to Thylacosmilus in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: dimorphodon-peters11
image:image.image:caption: Click to enlarge. Squamates, tritosaurs and fenestrasaurs in the phylogenetic lineage preceding the origin of the Pterosauria.

image:image.image:title: Dimorphodon-Peters
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Click to enlarge. Squamates, tritosaurs and fenestrasaurs in the phylogenetic lineage preceding the origin of the Pterosauria.

image:image.image:title: fenestrasaurs588
image:image.image:caption: The origin of the Pterosauria from basal Fenestrasauria

image:image.image:title: Dimorphodon Nesbitt
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 1. These are the taxa that Nesbitt (2011) reports are sisters to the pterosaur Dimorphodon.

image:image.image:title: Dimorphodon Peters
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 2. A series of pterosaur sister taxa documenting an increasing number of pterosaurian traits, according to Peters (2000) and reptileevolution.com.

image:image.image:title: Sanz-Cosesaurus72-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Cosesaurus illustrated as a juvenile Macrocnemus by Sanz and Lopez-Martinez (1984).

image:image.image:title: Longisquama-skull700
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 4. A short history of Longisquama skull tracings. All workers have traced an antorbital fenestra, but Senter (2003) reported it was not present. Note the level of detail provided by the DGS method in the lower tracing.

image:image.image:title: senter-cosesaurus-skull300
image:image.image:caption: Fig. 3. Red arrow points to the antorbital fenestra without a fossa in Cosesaurus.

image:image.image:title: NJU-57003skull_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The skull of NJU-57003 reconstructed in animated layers for clarity. This is something the print media just cannot do as well. All elements are similar to those found earlier in other anurognathids.

image:image.image:title: NJU-57003skull_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The skull elements of NJU-57003 colored to help alleviate the chaos of the crushed specimen. See figure 3 for the same elements reconstructed.

image:image.image:title: NJU57003insitu
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The NJU-57003 specimen and outline drawing, both from Yang et al. 2018. Various membranes and the overlooked sternal complex are colored in here.

image:image.image:title: anurognathid_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LPT nesting Discodactylus with Vesperopterylus within the Anurognathidae.

image:image.image:title: mole_cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on Carnivora, the basalmost eutherian clade. Talpa is the European mole. Shrews and shrew-moles nest within the clade Glires.

image:image.image:title: Origin_of_moles_Herpestes_Prohesperocyon_Talpa
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Taxa in the origin and evolution of moles, Herpestes, Prohesperocyon and Talpa.

image:image.image:title: uropsilus-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The mole-shrew, Uropsilus, is not related to the mole, Talpa (Carnivora), but is related to the shrew (clade Glires).

image:image.image:title: Prohesperocyon-wilsoni-AMNH-127172
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Prohesperocyon was considered a basal dog in the video, but here nests between raccoons and mongooses + moles.

image:image.image:title: carnivora_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT focusing on Carnivora. Taxa included within the dog family in the video are highlighted in yellow.

image:image.image:title: hesperocyon_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Two Hesperocyon skulls in lateral view. Note the short, high muzzle, the raised postorbital process of the jugal, the giant, cat-like upper molar.

image:image.image:title: Hesperocyon_Gregarius2x588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Hesperocyon skeletons. Note the upraised claws.

image:image.image:title: Prohesperocyon-wilsoni-AMNH-127172
image:image.image:caption: Figure x. Prohesperocyon nests between Herpestes and Talpa in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: talpa_europaea-skull3views588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Talpa skull. If you look closely you can see the tiny orbit completely surrounded by bone. Note the transverse premaxilla and large canines in the colorful lateral view. This is in contrast to the drawing below it that appears to indicate a longer premaxilla that would have included the long caniniform teeth. The palate view confirms the small transverse premaxilla.

image:image.image:title: herpestes_ichneumon_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Herpestes skull. Note the complete postorbital ring, a rare trait in the Carnivora.

image:image.image:title: talpa588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Talpa the Eastern mole nests in the LRT with Herpestes the mongoose.

image:image.image:title: herpestes-skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Herpestes, the Egyptian mongoose, nests in the LRT with Talpa the Eastern mole.

image:image.image:title: oreopithecus_pelvis-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. From Rook et al. 1999 comparing an Oreopithecus ilium to that of Homo and Hylobates.

image:image.image:title: oreopithecus_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Tentative reconstruction of elements traced in the Oreopithecus in situ figure 1. Other elements added from other authors.

image:image.image:title: oreopithecus_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Oreopithecus in situ traced with colors. This fossil is imperfectly preserved and the skull is crushed like an eggshell.

image:image.image:title: kryptobaatar_moving-jaw588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Animation of the mandible of the multituberculate Kryptobaatar showing the sliding of the jaw joint producing separate biting and grinding actions, just like rodents, their closest relatives in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: mesozoic-eutheria588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Mesozoic euthrerians (placentals, in black). Later taxa in light gray. All taxa more primitive than Mesozoic taxa were likely also present in the Jurassic and Cretaceous. None appear after Onychodectes. Madagascar separated from Africa 165-135 mya, deep into the Cretaceous with a population of tenrecs attached. No rafting was necessary.Â

image:image.image:title: mesozoic_metatheria588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Mesozoic metatherians (in black), later taxa in gray. Whenever derived taxa are present in the Mesozoic (up to the Late Cretaceous) then ancestral taxa, or their sisters, were also present in the Mesozoic. Didelphis is extant, but probably unchanged since the Late Jurassic/Early Cretaceous.

image:image.image:title: mesozoic_prototheria588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Mesozoic prototherians + Megazostrodon, the last common ancestor of all mammals. Only two taxa (gray) are post-Cretaceous.

image:image.image:title: Eocene-primate_migration588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The North Pole during the earliest Eocene from the CR Scotese Paleomap project with early primate skulls added, each demonstrating a gradual accumulation of traits.

image:image.image:title: primates588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT focusing on Primates. Here New World monkeys, like Aotus, are more primitive than Old World monkeys, just the opposite of traditional thinking.

image:image.image:title: paleocene-eocene_atlantic588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. At the start of the Eocene this is the distance monkeys would have to raft to get to South America. This hypothesis is invalidated by today's blogpost.

image:image.image:title: primates_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT focusing on Primates. Here New World monkeys, like Aotus, are more primitive than Old World monkeys, just the opposite of traditional thinking. Archicebus nests between Darwinius + Tarsius and Aegyptopithecus.

image:image.image:title: human-skull-homo588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. Human (Homo) skull showing areas of the frontal bone that appear to match the postorbitals seen in Teilhardina and Archicebus.

image:image.image:title: primate-cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Traditional primate cladogram versus the LRT cladogram where South American (New World) monkeys arise directly from North American (New World) adapids.

image:image.image:title: teilhardina588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Teilhardina skull with color overlays. Note the distinct postorbital bone here, too.

image:image.image:title: archicebus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Archicebus elements in situ and in vivo with colors added.

image:image.image:title: amphicyon_idoneus_compared588

image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT featuring Ochotona and the rabbits.

image:image.image:title: Triassic-Cretaceous_mammals588

image:image.image:title: Triassic-Cretaceou_mammals588

image:image.image:title: haramiyavia_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Haramiyavia reconstructed and restored. Missing parts are ghosted. Three slightly different originals are used for the base here. The last appears to be the least manipulated and it appears to fit the premaxilla better. Â The fourth maxillary tooth appears to be a small canine. The groove on the dorsal premaxillary appears to be for the nasal, not the septomaxilla. Parts are taken from both mandibles

image:image.image:title: Triassic-Jurassic
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Origin and radiation of mammals in the Norian (Late Triassic) based on the presence of a derived mammal, Haramiyavia, in the latest Triassic. Dinosaurs were diversifying then. So were mammals. This chart shows just how few mammal taxa are known for large portions of the Mesozoic.Â

image:image.image:title: Patriofelis-mount588

image:image.image:title: marsupial-ontogeny-Horovitz588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. A cladogram of metatherian mammals based on skeletal and soft traits by Horovitz and SÃ¡nchez-Villagra 2003. This cladogram lacks a large number of carnivorous metatherians, a large number of basal prototheres and a large number of basal eutherians. On the other hand, the LRT is missing the uncolored taxa. Colors correspond to the metathere subset of the LRT (Fig. 3).Â Horovitz and SÃ¡nchez-Villagra 2003 recovered a monophyletic Diprotodontia in contrast to the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Zhongornis-pectoral
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Zhongornis pectorals as traced here and as traced by O'Connor and Sullivan (right).

image:image.image:title: Zhongornis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Zhongornis in situ.

image:image.image:title: theropod_phylogenetic_mini588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal theropods. Pink area are more or less goose-sized and smaller taxa.

image:image.image:title: Enaliosauria2012
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. The Enaliosauria. Omphalosaurus probably nested with Sinosaurosphargis at the very base of the Placodontia not far from the bases of other enaliosaurs and derived from a sister to Stereosternum, a mesosaur, and Claudiosaurus.

image:image.image:title: omphalosaurus-palate300
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Omphalosaurus palate with elements colorized. Note the huge expanded splenials.

image:image.image:title: omphalosaurus-skull
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Omphalosaurus nevadanus, MBG 1500, the Austria specimen, skull portion in situ, mandible parts, skull parts and reconstruction with matching colors based on Sinosaurosphargis, the only other taxon with such a large set of splenials. The premaxillae are wider than the dentaries. Distinct from Sinosaurosphargis, the premaxillae were much enlarged.

image:image.image:title: sinosaurosphargis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Sinosaurosphargis. Click for more information. Not sure about the anterior extent of the maxilla, here shown two ways. Ribs and gastralia like these are not known in Omphalosaurus, which has more plesiomorphic and typical looking ribs and gastralia.

image:image.image:title: omphalosaurus-skull
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Omphalosaurus nevadanus, MBG 1500, the Austria specimen, skull portion in situ, mandible parts, skull parts and reconstruction with matching colors based on Sinosaurosphargis, the only other taxon with such a large set of splenials.

image:image.image:title: pappochelys-overall800
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Pappochelys compared to placodont sister taxa and compared to the Schock and Sues reconstruction, which appears to have several scale bar errors and underestimated the number of dorsal vertebrae. Click to enlarge. So few ribs and vertebrae are known for Pappochelys that their order, size and number could vary from that shown here. Note the ribs of ParaplacodusÂ are also expanded. The number of dorsal vertebrae is unknown and probably more than nine based on sister taxa.

image:image.image:title: Pappochelys-tree800
image:image.image:caption: Figure x. Two subsets of the large reptile tree focusing on Pappochelys and its enaliosaur relatives (left) and turtle relatives (right). Shifting Pappochelys to turtles adds 37 steps.

image:image.image:title: pappochelys-tree2
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Second cladogram recovered by Schoch and Sues 2015 recovered by Bayesian analysis.

image:image.image:title: pappochelys-tree1
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. from Schoch and Sues 2015 with colors added here to denote clades recovered by the large reptile tree. This is their TNT analysis result.

image:image.image:title: pappochelys-skull-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Pappochelys skull compared to sister taxa including Palatodonta and the original reconstruction of Schoch and Sues.

image:image.image:title: Jeholopterus_counterplate_UV588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Jeholopterus counter plate in UV with brachiopatagium traced.

image:image.image:title: Jeholopterus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Reconstruction of Jeholopterus. This owl-like bloodslurper was covered with super soft pycnofibers to make it a silent flyer.

image:image.image:title: jeholopterus_egg588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Possible Jeholopterus premature egg in which embryo bones are not well calcified. Ribs and gastralia on a separate frame.

image:image.image:title: Jeholopterus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Jeholopterus GIF animation showing new left wing shape plus underlying debris, perhaps in the form of theropod feathers.

image:image.image:title: anchiornis_specimens588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Four specimens attributed to Anchiornis. Two of these nest apart from two others (see figure 2).

image:image.image:title: anchiornis_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Cladogram of taxa surrounding four specimens attributed to Anchiornis, which do not nest together in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Jeholopterus_tail588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. The tail of Jeholopterus in situ.

image:image.image:title: Jeholopterus2013-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Jeholopterus in lateral view. Note the extreme length of the dermal fibers, unmatched by other pterosaurs.

image:image.image:title: jeholopterus-recons2-1000
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Click to enlarge. Tracing of Jeholopterus using DGS. Dorsal view of Jeholopterus based on the tracing. Lower left images include an unidentified pair of semi-circles too large to be embryo upper temporal fenestrae (that was the first guess). The tail is not particularly short when stretched to its full length, despite the reduced length of the individual caudals. The red ellipse represents a hypothetical egg shape. The abdomen was not so wide. The ribs would have had a ventral component and direction, which they do not have here. Note the right angle femoral head, ideal for parasagittal locomotion, like a dinosaur.

image:image.image:title: Jeholopterushires-tail1000
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Jeholopterus tail. Click to enlarge.

image:image.image:title: Caudipteryx_zoui588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Caudipteryx preserves forelimb and tail feathers, but no leg or foot feathers. It nests with oviraptorids in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: feather_foot_theropods
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Where feathers on the foot are preserved on the LRT.

image:image.image:title: Evolution-of-leg-feathers-in-coelurosaurian-dinosaurs-Four-major-stages-in-the-evolution
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. From Zheng et al. 2013 showing the maximum extent of hind leg feathers in Anchiornis.

image:image.image:title: doswellia-mandible2-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Doswellia restored two ways using two species. In this restoration, the pmx ascending process is gracile and missing, along with the anterior naris. The insert shows the vestige of the lateral temporal fenestra. If the large specimen includes an orbit and jugal here is a new reconstruction reflecting that change.

image:image.image:title: vancleavea_cas588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Vancleavea is a thalattosaur with 3D preservation.

image:image.image:title: Xiaotingia_Thermopolis_compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Xiaotingia, the proximal outgroup to the Thermopolis specimen of Solnhofen birds, the basalmost bird.

image:image.image:title: Mammalodon_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figue 1. Mammalodon nests within the clade Anthracobune basal to desmostylians and mysticetes.

image:image.image:title: giant_eudibamus588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. Eudibamus scaled to femoral (=long bone) lengths of 10 and 24 cm. This makes the giant eudibamid either half a meter or a meter in snout-vent length.

image:image.image:title: Anagale-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Anagale nests at the base of the tenrec - odontocete clade, not with rabbits, in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: pectoral_girdle588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Pectoral girdle of the Daiting specimen wrongly attributed to Archaeopteryx showing the clavicle (cv=furcula), scapula (sc), and the disc-like coracoids (co). Strap-like coracoids occur in more derived taxa and this shape marks the genesis of flapping.

image:image.image:title: Archaeopteryx_Daiting_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The skull of the Daiting specimen wrongly attributed to Archaeopteryx reconstructed from ÂµCT scans.

image:image.image:title: Daiting_Archaeopteryx_insitu
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Daiting specimen attributed to Archaeopteryx in white and UV light. Note the short coracoid. This is not a flapping tetrapod.

image:image.image:title: archaeopteryx_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Subset of the LRT focusing on basal birds and pre-bird theropods. Note many of the various Solnhofen birds nest apart from one another and the Daiting specimen nests outside the birds (Aves).

image:image.image:title: Desmatophoca_oregonensis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Desmatophoca skull. This extinct sea lion nests with Enaliarctos, not Phoca, the seal.

image:image.image:title: Mesadactylus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Mesadactylus restored from available data as an anurognathid.

image:image.image:title: basal_lepidosauromorpha588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the LRT: basal lepidosauromorpha, featuring Caseasauria.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. OMNH 708, a Permian pareiasaur horn form the Karoo, South Africa.

image:image.image:title: cow_skull
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. A modern cow skull horn most closely resembles the Permian pareiasaur horn, by convergence, of course.

image:image.image:title: pareiasaur-horn-OK-recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Elginia and OMNH 708 at two scales.

image:image.image:title: soft-shell-turtles250

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Sphodrosaurus in situ with colors added to bones and possible soft carapace impression.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Small pareiasaur humeri from Benton 2016. Note the scale bars. Some of these are smaller than Sclerosaurus (diagram), yet none are slenderized as in turtles.

image:image.image:title: Trionyx-evolution
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Soft shell turtle evolution featuring Arganaceras, Sclerosaurus, Odontochelys and Trionyx.

image:image.image:title: small-pareiasaur-forelimbs
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Small pareiasaur humeri. Note the scale bars. Some of these are smaller than Sclerosaurus, yet none are slenderized as in turtles.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Hard shell turtle evolution featuring Bunostegos, Elgenia, Meiolania and Proganochelys - NOT to scale.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Hard shell turtle evolution with Bunostegos, Elginia, Meiolania and Proganochelys.

image:image.image:caption: Figure1. The plate and counter plate of Sclerosaurus, an ancestral taxon to soft shell turtled. Girdles and extremities are reconstructed.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Mistralazhdarcho compared to reconstructions of Shenzhoupterus and Nemicolopterus.

image:image.image:title: Tinodon_bellus-YMP11843
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Tinodon is best represented by an incomplete mandible with affinities to basal mammals.

image:image.image:title: lanthanotus-compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Heloderma, Lanthanotus, Anilius, Cylindrophis, Uropeltis, and Leptotyphlops to scale. Boxed scales are enlarged.

image:image.image:title: leptotyphlops-jaws
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Click to animate. Leptotyphlops jaws move medially, not up and down. For this reason alone, Leptotyphlops is the most derived snake, not the most primitive one.

image:image.image:title: trogon-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Quetzalcoatlus (a type of trogon, genus: Pharomachrus mocinno) skeleton, skull and invivo presentation.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull of Plotosaurus. Note the mislabeling of the right supratemporal as a squamosal.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Leptoceratops in situ 2x. This taxon resolves the headless and head only node at the base of the ceratopsians in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: coronodon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Coronodon, was originally considered a toothed mysticete, but only in the absence of desmostylians, the real ancestors of mysticetes.

image:image.image:title: rodents_to_scale588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. A selection of taxa from figure 1 more or less to scale and in phylogenetic order (pink arrows). Hope this helps with the concept of a gradual accumulation of traits. The hedgehogs Erinaceus and Echinops are transitional to the higher taxa with teeth and without.

image:image.image:title: erinaceus_ignacius588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The hedgehog, Erinanceus, compared to Ignacius from the Paleocene.

image:image.image:title: rodents588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on the clade of rodents, shrews, rabbits and multituberculates. White taxa have a small or large tooth gap between the incisors and premolars.

image:image.image:title: archosauromorph_extinction588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. 2-frame GIF. The circle cladogram is from Allen et al. 2018. The overlay shows clades recovered by the LRT. Click to enlarge and make legible.

image:image.image:title: Aquilops_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Aquilops skull as restored and as discovered.

image:image.image:title: Ornithischia_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Aquilops nests at the base of psittacosaurs + ceratopsians in the LRT. Pachycephalosaurs, like Stegoceras, are not the sisters to ceratopsians.

image:image.image:title: Ornithischia_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Aquilops nests at the base of psittacosaurs + ceratopsians in the LRT. Pachycephalosaurs, like Stegoceras, are not the sisters to ceratopsians.

image:image.image:title: triceratops_juvenile_recon
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2b. Original figure from Goodwin et al. of juvenile Triceratops, but mandible and squamosal scale bars don't match. Then compared to an adult. Then reconstructed based on new mandible/squamosal proportions based on text measurements. Evidently the juvenile Trike had a longer rostrum than Goodwin thought.

image:image.image:title: juvenile_triceratops1
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Juvenile Triceratops compared to subadult Triceratops (in shadow).

image:image.image:title: Yinlong_skull
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Yinlong skull showing possible postfrontal in the position of the future orbit horns.

image:image.image:title: triceratops_lateral_blue-repaired588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Triceratops mount from an auction house. Pectoral girdle repaired. Skull colorized. Dorsal view comes from another specimen - always a dangerous proposition.

image:image.image:title: aquilops3D588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Digital reconstruction of Aquilops. Click to go to the 3D page.

image:image.image:title: Aquilops_Triceratops_Skulls588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Tiny Aquilops sits atop the nasal of its descendant, Triceratops, in this Sam Noble Museum photo.

image:image.image:title: PeruStone
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Short segment of a Peruvian stone wall with precision stone carving. One solution is to first create this as a precisely carved street, then disassemble it and reassemble it vertically to create the wall.

image:image.image:title: eoraptor_insitu
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. There is a strap of bone near the anterior coracoid, but it was correctly identified as a distal rib.

image:image.image:title: Eoraptor_clavicle588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Eoraptor does not preserve clavicles, but it does appear to preserve clavicle anchors.

image:image.image:title: rapetosaurus_and_kin588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Rapetosaurus skull compared to other sauropods.

image:image.image:title: Rapetosaurus_bipedal588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Rapetosaurus in traditional quadrupedal and imagined bipedal poses. Here that giant pubis is carrying a big gut.

image:image.image:title: arctodus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Arctodus (short-faced bear) skull in lateral view. Compare to figure 4.

image:image.image:title: arctodus_skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Arctodus (shor-faced bear) skeleton compared to the smaller Gulo (wolverine) skeleton. Both have similar proportions. Arctodus is larger than 3m, while Gulo is about 1m in length.

image:image.image:title: wolverine_skull_lateral588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Gulo skull in lateral and dorsal views. Compare to Arctodus in figure 5.

image:image.image:title: wolverine_skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Long-legged Gulo, the wolverine, is most similar to Arctodus, the short-faced bear in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: sauropod-skulls588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Several sauropod skulls to scale with DGS colors on the bones. Here are Shunosaurus, Camarasaurus, Brachiosaurus and Diplodocus.

image:image.image:title: sauropod-palates588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Sauropodiform and sauropod palates, Yizhousaurus, Diplodocus, Camarasaurus and Brachiosaurus. The choanae (internal nares) get bigger in sauropods.

image:image.image:title: camarasaurus_manus_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Reconstructions of manus and pes of Camarasaurus SMA0002 from Tschopp et al.

image:image.image:title: phytodinosauria2018
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT focusing on the Phytodinosauria. Three sauropods are added here.

image:image.image:title: brachiosaurus_illustration588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Family of Brachiosaurus illustration from A Dinosaur Year 1989.

image:image.image:title: carnivora_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on the Carnivora with tan tones on the bears newly added.

image:image.image:title: jinguofortis_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Jinguofortis perplexus reconstruction based on drawings in Wang, Stidham and Zhou 2018.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Jinguofortis skull in situ and reconstructed using DGS

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Jinguofortis perplexus in situ with interpretive drawing from Wang, Stidham and Zhou 2018.

image:image.image:title: A new symmetrodont mammal (Trechnotheria: Zhangheotheriidae) fro
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Theriodont pre-mammals to scale. Note the dentary-squamosal jaw joint developed by convergence in this clade.

image:image.image:title: kynodontia
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the LRT focusing on the Kynodontia and Mammalia. Non-eutherian taxa in red were tested in the LRT but not included because they reduce resolution. Eutherian taxa in red include a basal pangolin and derived xenarthran, clades that extend beyond the bottom of this graphic. The pink clade proximal to mammals was considered mammalian by Lautenschlager et al. due to a convergent mammalian-type jaw joint.

image:image.image:title: A new symmetrodont mammal (Trechnotheria: Zhangheotheriidae) fro
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Basal mammals and their proximal ancestors. Here taxa below Megazostrodon are mammals. Those above are not. Hadrocodium is uniquely reduced, but this occurs within the Mammalia. Â The dual jaw joint was tentatively present in Pachygenelus.

image:image.image:title: hadrocodium_color_bones
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Hadrocodium. So tiny that it was the size of the juveniles of sister taxa.

image:image.image:title: kynodontia_skulls588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Kynodontia to scale. The miniaturization of the ancestors of mammals had its genesis long before the proximal ancestors of mammals.

image:image.image:title: mammal-jaws_Lautenschlager2018revised
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Modified from figure 1 in Lautenschlager et al. 2018 with the addition of a cyan and magenta band keyed to pre-mammals and mammals in the LRT. Note the oddly large Repenomamus and Vincelestes in the original work. They don't belong where they are placed.

image:image.image:title: mammals1
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Subset of the large reptile tree focusing on mammals and their immediate ancestors. Here a few more taxa have been added, many from the Early and Late Cretaceous. Vincelestes, Repenomamus, Ernanodon, Asioryctes, Liaoconodon and Jeholodens are among them.

image:image.image:title: jeholodens-insitu_pes250
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Tarsus of Jeholodens with elements colorized as in other taxa.

image:image.image:title: rat_pes250
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Rattus pes. Note distal tarsal 4 only backs up pedal digit 4 and digit 5 rides alongside.

image:image.image:title: multituberculate_tarsus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The tarsus of Jeholodens compared to that of a cynodont, mutituberculate and Didelphis, a marsupial (metatherian).

image:image.image:title: jeholodens-insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Jeholodens holotype. Note the tip of the snout is missing, and so are the large anterior premaxillary teeth that characterize this clade.

image:image.image:title: Spinolestes-xenarthrosus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Spinolestes with bones colorized in DGS and both manus and skull reconstructed.

image:image.image:title: vincelestes-skull-lat300
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Vincelestes skull. Note the many differences in tooth size and count here along with the shorter rostrum on this basal Cretaceous carnivore.

image:image.image:title: Asioryctes_Monodelphis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skulls of mammals at or near the Metatheria/Eutheria split. Here Asioryctes has four pairs of molars, like Didelphis and Monodelphis. Leptictis also has four pairs of molars.

image:image.image:title: Mammal_family_tree588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. New mammal family tree, a subset of the large reptile tree. Here one can trace a gradual accumulation of derived traits, something the traditional paradigm fails to do. Here the clade names in black refer to small discrete clades in the gray column at right. The red clade names refer to taxa identified by color bars

image:image.image:title: basal_mammals
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Basal mammals begin with Ornithorynchus, the most primitive living mammal. Yanoconodon nests just outside this clade.

image:image.image:title: yanoconodon_middle_ear
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. From Luo et al. the posterior jaw bones of Yanoconodon. These are not middle ear bones, so Yanoconodon is not a mammal.

image:image.image:title: yanoconodon588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 1. Yanaconodon nests as the proximal outgroup to the Mammalia in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: liaoconodon-hui-skull-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Liaocondon skull traced and reconstructed. In the LRT it most closely resembles that of Probainognathus. Note the enormous size of the temporal fenestrae, the downturned squamosals and postdentary bones, all shared with Probainognathus.

image:image.image:title: liaoconodon_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Liaoconodon in situ.

image:image.image:title: probainognathus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Probainognathus skull(s) in several views along with a pectoral and pelvic girdle.

image:image.image:title: liaoconodon-hui-skull-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Liaocondon skull traced and reconstructed. In the LRT it most closely resembles that of Probainognathus.

image:image.image:title: Asioryctes_Bishops588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The dentary of Bishops compared to its Late Cretaceous sister, Asioryctes, which has fewer and larger premolars.

image:image.image:title: camarasaurus-skulls588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Several skulls attributed to Camarasaurus to scale. SMA 0002 is the short-limbed Cathetosaurus. Brachiosaurus appears to be a derived camarasaur.

image:image.image:title: hipposaurus_dimetropus

The LRT only tests more completely known taxa.Â

image:image.image:title: Kulindadromaeus-recon
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Kulindadromaeus, a sister to Heterodontosaurus with proto-feathers. Images from and traced from Godefroit et al. 2014. Since theropods and heterodontosaurs both had something like feathers, if they were the same kind of feathers, their last common ancestor had feathers. That last common ancestor was a herrerasaur or its proximal predecessor. Note the Godefroit et al. skull does not match their description but has a standard maxilla ascending process. See color examples for correct ed interpretation. Click to enlarge.

image:image.image:title: scleromochlus-scales

Manual digit 4.4 is buried beneath other bones and reemerges to give its length. Pedal digit 1 turns laterally due to metacarpal arcing and taphonomic crushing. There is nothing reversed about it.Â

image:image.image:title: Vesperopterylus-lamadongensis-_skull_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Vesperopterylus skull with bones identified by DGS (digital graphic segregation). LÃ¼ et al. were not able to discern these bones and so left the area blank in their tracing. Note the complete lack of a giant eyeball in the front of the skull. Radius and ulna were removed for clarity and to show a complete lack of giant eyeballs (sclerotic rings) in the anterior skull.Â

image:image.image:title: JPM-2012-001recon588

image:image.image:title: anurognathid_JPM-2012-001insitu

image:image.image:title: metatheria
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Subset of the large reptile tree focusing on the Metatheria. The tree is fully resolved, but many bootstrap scores under 50 indicate that only one or two characters separate those nodes with low scores. Scores higher than 50 are separated by three or more traits.

image:image.image:title: Procoptodon-Interatherium588
