image:image.image:title: volaticotherium_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Volaticotherium reconstructed. Here the patagium appears to be able to just drape over the head and torso, unlike the much larger membrane in Cynocephalus, the flying lemur. Shown as a biped here, that was likely only a temporary pose, like a squirrel on itsÂ haunches. Occipital bones are not shown.

image:image.image:title: monodelphis_and_pups588

image:image.image:title: basal-therians300

image:image.image:title: volaticotherium_recon588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Volaticotherium reconstructed and compared to its sister in the LRT, Monodelphis. Here the patagium appears to be able to just drape over the head and torso, unlike the much larger membrane in Cynocephalus, the flying lemur. Shown as a biped here, that was likely only a temporary pose, like a squirrel on tis haunches. Occipital bones are not shown.

image:image.image:title: argentoconodon

image:image.image:title: catchers-mitt-evolution
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Everything evolves, even catcher's mitts. By analogy, bat's wings evolved to become better catcher's mitts.

image:image.image:title: ptilocercus-invivo
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Ptilocercus in vivo, holding prey with its small hands while eating it.

image:image.image:title: ptilocercus-bat1000
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Ptilocercus, Icaronycteris and a hypothetical transitional taxon based on the ontogenetically immature wing of the embryo Myotis. If you're going to evolve wings it looks like you have to stop using them as hands early on. Note in the bat embryo there is little indication of inter-metacarpal muscle. That area looks identical to the web.

image:image.image:title: bat-scapula-compared
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Bat and human scapula compared. Red arrows point to acromion process, reduced and moved away from the shoulder joint in bats to enable greater freedom of motion.

image:image.image:title: fruit_bat_skeleton800
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Fruit bat (Pteropus) skeleton with hypothetical muscles added).

image:image.image:title: pentailed-tree-shrew
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The pen-tailed tree shrew, Ptilocercus, the closest living non-flying relative of bats. Note the pose, perpendicular to the narrow branch. It arrived there by leaping from one branch to another, rather than walking along the length of the branch. When pen tailsÂ

image:image.image:title: bat-anterior-flight
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Bat flight stroke in anterior view. This is a different stroke than birds or pterosaurs used, depending more on elbow and finger flexure and extension.

image:image.image:title: Chriacus-Onychonycteris-1000
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Chriacus and Onychonycteris nest as a sister to the undiscovered bat ancestor and a basal bat. Miniaturization was part of the transition. So was enlargement of the manus. It is still a mystery why the transitional form decided to start flapping.

image:image.image:title: bat-origins
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. A few bats and kin have been added to the large reptile tree. Surprisingly enough traits are present to resolve their relationships without getting into too many dental traits.

image:image.image:title: onychonycteris1000
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Selected details of Ptilocercus and Onychnycteris.

image:image.image:title: cynocephalus588

image:image.image:title: ptilocercus-bat1000
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ptilcercus (above) and Icaronycteris (below), sister taxa in the origin of bats.

image:image.image:title: bat_origins_cladogram588

image:image.image:title: battree250
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Bat evolution and origins from the Carnivora/Viverridae. They are sisters to the Pen-tailed tree shrew and colugos among living taxa. Protictis is an extinct outgroup taxon from the Paleocene.

image:image.image:title: bat-tree250
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Bat evolution and origins

image:image.image:title: Cifelliodon_Tachyglossus_skulls
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Early Cretaceous Cifelliodon is ancestral to the living echidna, Tachyglossus according to the LRT. The lack of teeth here led to toothlessness in living echidnas. The skull of Tachyglossus is largely fused together, lacks teeth and retains only a tiny lateral temporal fenestra (because the jaws don't move much in this anteater. Compared to Cifelliodon the braincase is greatly expanded, the lateral arches are expanded and the two elements fuse, unlike most mammals.

image:image.image:title: Quetzalcoatlus_Ciconia_Pelagornis_dorsal_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Q. northropi and Q. sp. compared to Ciconia, the stork, and Pelagornis, the extinct gannet, to scale. That long neck and large skull of Quetzalcoatlus would appear to make it top heavy relative to the volant stork, despite the longer wingspan. Pteranodon and other flying pterosaurs do not have such a large skull at the end of such a long neck (Fig. 1). The longer wings of pelagornis show what is typical for a giant volant tetrapod, and Q. sp. comes up short in comparison.

image:image.image:title: Quetzalcoatlus_MacReady_model588

image:image.image:title: snake-origins-tree
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. A subset of the large reptile tree focusing on squamates. Note terrestrial snake ancestors are sisters to basal geckos. Burrowing snakes are sisters to Heloderma and Lanthanotus. It took the removal of all the light green boxed taxa to shift terrestrial snakes over to the base of the burrowing snakes and then Pontosaurus shifted over to the base of the varanids.

image:image.image:title: raeticodactylus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Raeticodactylus skull. Above, in situ and as originally interpreted. Middle: DGS tracing in color. Below: Reconstruction in lateral and palatal views. The missing part of the jugal may have lodged over quadrate, as it appears. The postorbital is broken into several pieces. The nasal extends a laminated layer over the premaxilla. The posterior pterygoid process is broken in situ and repaired here. One vomer is aligned with the premaxilla/maxilla suture. An ectopalatine (ectopterygoid + palatine) is displaced beneath the lacrimal. The mandible bones do not match the original drawing, but are closer to Eudimorphodon and other sister taxa. In all pterosaurs, the dentary approaches the coronoid process.

image:image.image:title: caviramus-raeticodactylus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Caviramus (above) compared to Raeticodactylus (below) to the same length (on left) and to scale (on right). Caviramus mandible in lateral view showing the bony medial supports for the anterior teeth. The apparent mandible fenestra in Caviramus perhaps represents a missing coronoid.

image:image.image:title: Austriadactylus-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Austriadactylus (holotype) skull. Currently, with so few Triassic pterosaurs know, this is a sister to Raeticodactylus.

image:image.image:title: desmodus_uropatagium588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. A plesiomorphic bat with the tail incorporated in the uropatagium. This bat, Myotis, cannot walk very well. Desmodus, highly derived, has required the ability to walk, but at the expense of its tail and a vestige uropatagium.

image:image.image:title: bat_witton_uropatagium588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Above, from Witton 2017 focusing on the pterosaur uropatagium. Note: even though fanciful, it does not incorporate the tail, but goes from leg to leg, UNLIKE Desmodus the bat, which incorporates what little tail is left.

image:image.image:title: Confuciusornis_berlin_skull_588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1A. Berlin Confuciusornis skull as traced by Elzanowski et al. and colorized here. Note the postorbital is broken during crushing. Hyoids are misidentified. Lacrimal and teeth are overlooked. The vomer and palatine are peeking out from the anterior maxilla. The plesiomorphic diapsid temporal region is present here (contra Elzanowski et al. 2018).

image:image.image:title: confusciusornis_berlin588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The Berlin specimen assigned to Confuciusornis sanctus is preserved with a full set of feathers, including two long tail feathers. Surprisingly, the furcula came to rest on top of the neck.

image:image.image:title: Confuciusornis_berlin_skull_588

Lacrimal and teeth are overlooked. The vomer and palatine are peeking out from the anterior maxilla. The plesiomorphic diapsid temporal region is present here (contra Elzanowski et al. 2018).

image:image.image:title: elasmosaurid_origins588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Click to enlarge. Albertonectes reconstructed. This 11 m elasmosaur is the longest thusfar recorded. This may be the breathing pose, swallowing air, then submerging the neck. When horizontal the air could be passed back to the lungs, as hypothesized for Dinocephalosaurus.

image:image.image:title: jianchangopterus-painten-pterosaur588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. The Painten pterosaur phylogenetically nests between two smaller specimens in the LPT.Â

image:image.image:title: painten-pterodactylus_skull_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Painten pterosaur skull.

image:image.image:title: painten_skull_evolution588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Painten pterosaur ancestors and descendants.

image:image.image:title: painten-pterodactylus_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Painten pterosaur specimen in situ under visible and UV light, then under DGS to identify the bones with colors.

image:image.image:title: painten-pterodactylus_feet588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. The feet and tail of the Painten pterosaur with colors applied to bones. One loose proximal tail bone (red) is displaced at left. Left manual 4.4 is broken and re-healed in a jagged fashion. The wing tips are large, pulley-like joints. The wing unguals (dark blue) are displaced.

image:image.image:title: painten-pterodactylus_m5
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The wrist of the Painten pterosaur. Here the vestige of manual digit 5 (blue) is clearly visible on the palmar side of the left wrist.

image:image.image:title: Painten-ptero-compared800
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Click to enlarge. Painten pterosaur compared to phylogenetic sister taxa. Ornithocephalus and SMNS 81775 are the basal taxa here. Note that while everything else grows on derived taxa, the metacarpus stays the same size. The large size of the Painten pterosaur, along with the greater length of pedal digit 3 and the brevity of the metacarpus sets it apart in its own clade, of which this the first known representative. Larger than its relatives, this is an unlikely juvenile (contra Hone, see below).

image:image.image:title: Painten-manual-digit5
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Virtually undisturbed right wing with manual digit 5, a wee soft vestige, still present (blue arrow and enlarged insert). Green arrow points to pteroid articulating with radiale (proximal syncopal). Red arrow points to extensor tendon process.

image:image.image:title: darwinopterus-rhamphodactylus-painten
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. The Painten pterosaur, Darwinopterus and "Rhamphodactylus" to scale showing their variety and their transitional status.

image:image.image:title: FPainten-Ptero-foot-ungual5-800
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Here are the unguals for pedal digit 5. One on edge tucked between other bones and the other flattened on top of the metatarsal.

image:image.image:title: FPainten-Ptero-foot588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Painten pterosaur foot. Tischlinger and Frey note that digit 5 has no claw (ungual) but it's there, just hard to see (Fig. 2). What is easy to see is the interphalangeal joint at the tip of p5.2. So why a joint with no ungual? Looking harder always helps.

image:image.image:title: Pantien-pterosaur588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The Painten pterosaur (privately owned) from Frey and Tischlinger 2013. Excellent preservation and preparation here.

image:image.image:title: cf.Tupuxuara
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Early Cretaceous cf.Tupuxuara from the Elgin 1914 dissertation. This taxon nests between the Solnhofen specimen B St 1878 VI 1 and Eopteranodontia + Pteranodontia in the LPT, far from Tupuxuara. Reconstruction from underlying in situ specimen from the Elgin 2014 dissertation available online.

image:image.image:title: cf.Tupuxuara_and_kin
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The cf.Tupuxuara specimen is larger than sister taxa in the LPT.

image:image.image:title: cacibupteryx588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Cacibupteryx ( IGO-V 208) to scale with the 2470/1 specimen attributed to Sordes. These two nest together in the large pterosaur tree, not quite with Sordes. These two were contemporaries, both from the Tropic of Capricorn, not a world apart, as they are now, but part of the supercontinent Pangaea prior to the appearance of the North Atlantic.

image:image.image:title: 3Sordes1000
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. The three Sordes specimens to scale. They are close, but not identical. Shown above each is a closer sister taxon.

image:image.image:title: Sordes-wing-peters-2002
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Sordes wing drift hypothesis from Peters (2002) which attempted to show that the wings and uropatagia of Sordes were more like those of other pterosaurs than the other way around. The very deep uropatagia are misinterpretations prior to the realization that the left brachiopatagium (main wing membrane) was displaced to the ankle area.

image:image.image:title: Sordes_2585-25insitu
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The PIN 2585-25 specimen of Sordes.

image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Click to enlarge. Three hypotheses for humeral configuration in pterosaurs. Left: Greg Paul's lateral humerus. Middle left: Mark Witton's vertical humerus. Middle right and far right: My obliquely posterior orientation based on putting model bones together.

image:image.image:title: eotyrannus-recon588

image:image.image:title: eotyrannus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The bits and pieces of Eotyrannus restored as a skull. It appears the original nasal is actually the nasal + frontal and some lateral bones.

image:image.image:title: gorgosaurus_eotyrannus_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The bits and pieces of Eotyrannus placed to scale on the skull of Gorgosaurus. Blue image is from the authors. Nasal was described as 22cm, but is more like 40 cm.

image:image.image:title: hemicentetes.skull.asymmetry588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Hemicentetes an extant echolocating tenrec, also has a twisted skull, like its descendants, the odontocete whales.

image:image.image:title: fahlke_odontocete_asymmetry588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull asymmetry in odontocete whales from Fahlke et al. 2011.

image:image.image:title: tursiops_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. Common bottle nose dolphin skull (genus: Tursiops) also displays a bit of asymmetry in dorsal view.

image:image.image:title: fetal_narwhal588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Fetal narwhal skull, here colorized from Nweenia et al. 2012. The jugal disappears in adults.

image:image.image:title: Delphinapterus
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The beluga, Delphinapterus, is closely related to, though less derived than the narwhal, Monodon. More teeth of a regular shape were present in the jaws. Those two yellow arrows indicate a misalignment of the centerline of the top of the occiput vs. the bottom. Compare to figure 3.

image:image.image:title: narwhal_skull_lat588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Distinct from most narwhals, this skull also has right tusk emerging from the canine position. And yes, that's the maxilla covering most of the skull, even above the orbit! I added an eyeball here to help locate the orbit. The mesethmoid is the red bone that divides the naris (blow hole).

image:image.image:title: narwhal_CTscan
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. CT scans of a female narwhal (Monodon) showing soft tissues and unerupted teeth. Note the angle of the posterior skull relative to the anterior.

image:image.image:title: narwhal_tusk_roots
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Image from Nweeia et al. 2012 showing the unerupted right tusk and the root of the left tusk in the male narwhal along with two unerupted tusks in the female.

image:image.image:title: odontocetes
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Subset of the LRT focusing on the tenrec/odontocete clade with several whales added.

image:image.image:title: chonecetus_goedertorum_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Chonecetus has a more primitive skull with nares closer to the snout tip and no maxilla above the orbit.

image:image.image:title: Untitled-1
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. Subset of the LRT focusing on the Iguania. Gray box are extinct taxa.

image:image.image:title: Phrynosoma588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 6. Phyronosoma, the horned lizard of North America.

image:image.image:title: Moloch_horridus588
image:image.image:caption: FIgure 4. Moloch in vivo. At present this is the closest relative of the flying dragon, Draco volans, in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: moloch_overall588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Skeleton of Moloch from Digimorph.org with certain bones colorized here.

image:image.image:title: moloch_skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Skull of Moloch horridus, from Digimorph.org, with bones colored here.

image:image.image:title: avicranium_cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 4. Subset of the LRT focusing on drepanosaurs and Avicranium.

image:image.image:title: avicranium-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Avicranium from Pritchard and Nesbitt 2017, in situ, original reconstruction and revised with rostral restoration.

image:image.image:title: dracula-pterosaur588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Dracula the giant azhdarchid pterosaur museum mount. Hopefully it's not too late to fix the problems here.

image:image.image:title: macrocephalon-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Macrocephaloon nests with the hoatzin, Opisthocomus in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: sphenodontia_cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Cladogram of the Sphenodontia includes Colobops and rhynchosaurs.

image:image.image:title: pritchard cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Cladogram from Pritchard et al. failed to include a long list of basal sphenodontians, including Marmoretta, the sister to Colobops in the LRT. Note the shuffling of lepidosauromorph and archosauromorphs in this cladogram, lacking any broad resemblance to the LRT tree topology.

image:image.image:title: colobops-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Colobops as originally presented and slightly restored.

image:image.image:title: daffy_flying
image:image.image:caption: Figure 8. Daffy Duck in "To Duck or Not to Duck" 1943 uses the quad fly method. See figure 1 for comparable take-off technique.

image:image.image:title: pteranodon-over-water-gif_medium
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. GIF animation from the American Museum of Natural History showing how their Pteranodon managed to hop off the surface of the water until suddenly able to flap and fly. Totally bogus.

image:image.image:title: Sylviornis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Sylviornis is not a giant chicken. It's a basal predatory bird.

image:image.image:title: ascendonanus_pes588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 5. Ascendonanus pes.

image:image.image:title: Ascendonanus_cladogram
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Ascendonanus cladogram, subset of the LRT. Here Ascendonanus nests with iguanids, not varanopids.

image:image.image:title: Ascendonanus_nestleri_skull
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The skull of Ascendonanus has a diapsid temporal configuration with clearly visible upper temporal fenestra and a typical iguanid skull morphology.

image:image.image:title: Ascendonanus-nestleri588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Ascendonanus nestler is an Early Permian lepidosaur nesting with Saniwa, a member of the Varanoidea.

image:image.image:title: Ixalerpeton-polesinensis588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Ixalerpeton bits and pieces reconstructed. This taxon nests with protorosaurs.

image:image.image:title: ascendonanus-holotype-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. The Ascendonanus holotype skull as originally traced and as traced here.

image:image.image:title: Prodiapsida588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The Prodiapsida now include the holotypes of Ascendonanus and Anningia.

image:image.image:title: Ascendosaurus-Spindler_cladogram588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Cladogram from Spindler et al. 2018. Colors refer to clades in the LRT.

image:image.image:title: ascendonanus-specimens-compared588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. The five specimens from the Ascendonanus quarry, all to the same scale. Most images from Spindler et al. 2018. Some have skulls 3x the occiput/acetabulum length. Others as much as 5x, the first hint that these taxa are no conspecific.

image:image.image:title: MycterosaurusFMNH-UC169-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Mycterosaurus based on Berman and Reisz 1982.

image:image.image:title: archaeovenator588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Archaeovenator, a smaller relative of Anningia, itself a synapsid outgroup to the Diapsida.

image:image.image:title: galesphyrus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 3. Galesphyrus, a basal protodiapsid from the same horizon as Anningia.

image:image.image:title: archaeovenator588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Archaeovenator, a smaller relative of Anningia, itself a synapsid outgroup to the Diapsida.

image:image.image:title: anningia588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Anniningia megalops as illustrated by Romer and Price 1940 (below) and in two views from Reisz and Dilkes 1992 with elements colorized and hypothetical rostrum and jaws added.

image:image.image:title: caseosaurus_pelvis-animation588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. GIF animation comparing the holotype pelvis of Caseosaurus (big and red) to the referred material (small and blue). Perhaps you are asking yourself, what were these authors thinking? The two pelves are not even congeneric.

image:image.image:title: Trionyx-turtle-skeleton588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 7. Trionyx, an African soft-shelled turtle with fossil relatives back to the Cretaceous nests with Odontochelys.

image:image.image:title: carettochelys.3views588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Carettochelys in 3 views from Digimorph.org and used with permission.

image:image.image:title: IVPP-V-18048-Perochelys-lamadongensis-skull588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. Perochelys skull in dorsal and ventral views.

image:image.image:title: Perochelys_insitu588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Perochelys (Early Cretaceous) in situ

image:image.image:title: earlypermianreptile1000
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Click to enlarge. The Early Permian reptile (TA1045) preserved in volcanic debris, from RoÃler et al. 2012. Yes, those are transverse belly scales beneath the ribs.It looks like the complete rostrum was preserved, right to the edge of the matrix. This image is considered low in resolution. More details can be gleaned with better images.

image:image.image:title: earlypermianreptile1000
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Click to enlarge. The Early Permian reptile preserved in volcanic debris, from RoÃler et al. 2012.

image:image.image:title: crocliz
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. The large reptile tree pruned to match (as closely as possible) the taxon list from Ezcurra et al. Note the two branches found by the large reptile tree are here intertwined, as in the Ezcurra tree. This is due to taxon exclusion.

image:image.image:title: Ezurra-tree588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Tree recovered by Ezcurra et al. Colored areas are based on the large reptile tree, the new Lepidosauromorpha (pink) and the new Archosauromorpha (baby blue).

image:image.image:title: Jurassic-fossil-snakes
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Maxillae from several Mid-to-Late Jurassic snakes discovered by Caldwell et al. 2015, including Parviraptor, Diabolosphis and Portualophis.. These are compared to Lanthanotus, an extant limbed precursor to burrowing snakes, like Cylindrophis. Also shown are Eichstaettisaurus, a limbed varanid precursor to terrestrial snakes along with the skulls of Adriosaurus, an elongate limbed pre-snake and Pachyrhachis, a Late Cretaceous snake with vestigial hind limbs and no forelimbs or pectoral girdle.

image:image.image:title: Amphisbaenia-rafting
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. From Longrich et al. 2015, hypothetical rafting paths of burrowing skinks.

image:image.image:title: TA1045-588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 2. the TA!045 Permian varanid. This specimen sets the squamates back to the Early Permian and beyond to the Late Pennsylvanian.

image:image.image:title: Tamaulipasaurus588
image:image.image:caption: Figure 1. Tamaulipasaurus, a burrowing skink from the Early Jurassic, long before the breakup of Pangaea.
